description: absolutely quintessential mellow, authentic and cool sf vibe. let's keep on creating while they keep on hating.  loved it, would return (plus velvet and neon)
author: Georganne R.

description: Fun dive bar. Good drinks and service. Would definitely go here again. I also liked that it is a WSU Cougar bar!
author: Ed F.

description: There should be a part of me that wishes the old place didn't change, but  I think this has the potential to be a heck of a bar. Beautifully redone they did a great job. It'll be interesting to see how this place goes moving forward with no more "Old Men" and clean & modern toilets. It is now a bit of a hipster haven, complete with pretentious douche bags hanging out in there.  and it's weird, because it is definitely an old dive bar, yet they have made modern upgrades that kind of take some of the character and charm out of the dive category.
author: Ronald M.

description: I think the first time I came here was a wake for Charles Bukowski. It has gotten a lot cleaner since those days. Still has charm, though.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Definitely a dive bar playing lots of oldies. Their drinks were cheap and strong! They have a pool table if you like to play pool. Lots of places to sit. They also have a water refill station across from the bar. I think every bar should have one of these!!

We came here with some friends after the warriors game. It's a cool place to start your night or even finish it. Also a good place if you're looking for a chill place to grab some drinks.
author: Meghan P.

description:
No more Old Men, 2018. Beautifully redone with clean & modern toilets!
Love it! Love it! Love it!
Cold BEER.
author: Alton C.

description: Ask for Drew. Best service ever! Neighborhood favorite. Echos the spirit of yesteryear Hank & Ralph, who's gritty tenderloin culture can only be remotely remembered through the artifacts framed on the wall, in the photo booth or cryptic tv playing such favorites as scenes from Dirty Harry and Bullet.
author: Michael S.

description:
Ahh the HA-RA.  This bar holds a minor yet mystic mythic part of my history and is dear to my heart.  Many years ago I walked in with a internet date.   Rick behind the bar greeted me and somehow psychically knew my name.  We had never met before but he straight up guessed my full name.   He then quietly & solemnly took me aside when my date used the bathroom to tell me that my date had herpes.  My date was from another state, had only moved to SF days before & was quite squeaky clean vanilla, and there was no way he could have known him, but Rick told me he just knew and wanted to warn me.  Rick was captivating and fun.  I always dug his stories about growing up in the bar, his family's history, SFs history, and the buildings history. The place is just soaking in stories, very vibey. 

I would then run into Rick all the time in the TL over the next few years, and we would always have these great momentary transcendental conversations.  The last time I saw him, he was phasing out of bar scene and I figured the place would be sold, and hipped the hell up to some Disneyland idea of what millennials like, so I avoided going back. 

Until this weekend!  I was pleasantly surprised to feel the same charm and history I always felt at this TL hole.  Now there are just some sweet upgrades (nice tvs, beer keg tap tables), a little less crusty & more modern.  I love that the walls are still gushing with history, hate, love, laughing, fucking, fighting, its all still there.  Still the best Tenderloin Bar.
author: Chelsey G.

description: Drew is a 5 star bartender! Always greets you with a smile. Great neighborhood bar. Definitely my go-to.
author: Leslie S.

description:
Why 5...?  (Cue the dreamy "flashback-sequence" effect used for exposition in the 1980's and 1990's...)

Ha-Ra Club was the gritty survivor.  The echos stirred at this little way-past-its-prime lounge on Geary.  I liked going there and experiencing the post-modern impending demise of the last gasp of its era.  The bartender, while not your average guy, was a hell of a gentleman who had a lot of worldly wisdom.  Those who dwained to dwell in "old" Ha-Ra's environs were for real.  You knew it wouldn't last.  It effectively closed a while ago.  In my mind, this one was buried and dead.  (Finger.  No pulse.  ... He's dead, Jim.)  

(Flash Forward - Fade into a man walking down Geary on his way to a farmers market.)

10:30am, Temperature:  62.7 Degrees.  Purpose:  I'm on the way to the Fillmore Farmers Mar.... ....  ... (scratch) ... IS HA-RA BACK OPEN?!?! 

I wondered in.  And, my jaw dropped.  Dropped.  This place has been redone in a big way.  Then, I was blown away the more I hung out and talked to the folks.  They blew this remodel away.  I cannot believe how good a job they did off maintaining the original character of the bar while enhancing it into a modern setting.  Seeing the "old bar" and the "new bar" is something.  I loved the nostalgia, but to see a place that is above-average to begin with is quite a juxtaposition.  They opened up the area over the bar and it feels much more spacious.  The bar and behind the bar are the same as always.  The pool area is essentially the same with the addition of high-tops.  But, while retaining these classic elements, they did it up and it is beautiful.  I'd like to know if they used a professional designer - this was well done and someone deserves some props.  

There should be a part of me that wishes the old place didn't change, but I don't feel that way.  I think this has the potential to be a heck of a bar.  They did a great job.  And, it does stand-out against the back-drop of the neighborhood bars.  It'll be interesting to see how this place goes moving forward, but they have a foundation of a 60+ year-old bar that has a lot of good vibes.
author: Adam S.

description: A very nice neighborhood bar to try out it you are in the area. The drinks are good and the beer is cold. They have a pool table which was nice to use while you're drinking and enjoying your company. The service was nice, but I'm not sure if it was because we were there with some of the "regulars." A very nice place to hang out and chill. It was not too busy when we were there on a Friday night. A nice variety of music playing at a good level.
author: Camera P.

description:
Oh man, the best bar ever besides Aces. 
The owner is incredibly sweet, the people the all work there are the funniest/nicest staff you could meet. 
My dog is continuously being fed treats and I get nice and drunk, it works for both of us. 
Make sure to go when the bartender Adam is working, he is the best and also adorable.
author: Sari S.

description: From the dim lit room with red velvet wallpaper to the most charismatic bartender Hugo; You can't go wrong. Great place to meet with friends, play pool and escape the tensions of the TL.
author: Dave M.

description: This club is great! It has an old fashion photo booth that all my friends and I enjoyed. It's kinda dark in the club, however, that's what makes it fun. Would like to come back in the future for sure!
author: Alton W.

description: If you like vintage velvet flocked wallpaper, you'll like this spot. The bar is divey, has a mixed crowd, a tv usually playing the Giants or A's, and is clean and tidy. And a good spot for a nightcap. The Ha-Ra was opened in 1947 by Harry and Ray, a boxer and a police man (I think, I might have made that up). There's a blown up photo of them on the wall between the pool table and photo booth. The photobooth was converted by Photo-matica from the original 1950's era wooden phone booth (that you can see in that photo on the wall) after the bar was renovated a few years ago. #photoboothpubcrawlsf #sanfranciscophotoboothpubcrawl
author: Matt D.

description: Well you know, new wallpaper, ceilings, and...a real complete mens bathroom(no mirror). NO JUKEBOX. All one has to say is: What would Carl think?
author: Mag N.

description:
Almost hate to write this review because the conformist lames will infest however the truth is the light. Being a recent widow yeh, ouch... late Tuesday, June 14 I nocturnally strolled to Target downtown for cat food (mock me and you will be cursed)  and on the way I noticed that Ha-Ra Club had like, reasonably sane functional-looking and attractive people inside! One star!

Say wha? That place used to be an ultra freak fest in the worse possible way I'm 'old school' tolerant liberal artsy chick & have avoided Ha-Ra Club except for an unfortunate visit in the  late '90's with the late Mr. L to protect me it was too much yuck and I should know have lived here since 1984 (broken record). 

The handsome (I'm a sexist piglet) doorman accepted my smile and stepped to the side. See, some doormen are passive aggressive idiots and chose to bother a chick for no other reason than they feel less-than; nevermind the quasi- feminist rhetoric about misogynist impotence, which there isn't any at Ha-Ra Club.  Two stars.

What else do you want in a recently refurbished San Francisco iconic dive bar beside red velvet flocked walls and friendly talkative service men. Three stars.

Emphasis on men and being a str8 lady, well, honey, please.  Ladies and gentlemen, behold your newest Tendernob cruising/pick up/first date/bridge and tunnel joint. Four stars!

The  is a pool table, the house white wine is 7 bucks there are drinks specials, happy hours hooks for your purse to hang on (smile)  every nook and cranny is screaming for an infatuation kiss.

 Unless you get a wonky doorman then you will lose your mystique and right now Ha-Ra Club  deserves 5 stars.
author: SF T.

description: Continuing my review... it just keeps getting better. Drew is a stone fox and attentive. But straight up they are bringing some excellent door guys. Let's  start with Vince... Fast and furiously on top of  peeps that don't respect the bar. Noah he is  gentleman of door guys and always lights my cigarette. Hank he knows the stank.  The best blousy boobs in town keeps being brought by Sarah but that isn't just it. She has Star personality. Still no question she prevails beyond! Need I say more..,
author: Black D.

description: Nice neighborhood bar with a great relaxed vibe and a fun photo booth! My wife and I decided to stop by in the recommendation of a good friend! Glad we did!
author: Marc L.

description: We stopped by this place by accident what a great find great drinks and fantastic atmosphere super nice bartender and great pours
author: Johnny B.

description:
The new HA-RA is great!! I just threw my big birthday party on Saturday. I have to give them 2 thumbs up! They were so excited that I chose HA-RA for my party and very accommodating while I was planning and the actual day of the party. One of the owners Wizz and bartender Drew took time and met me and boyfriend in person to discuss the planning. They were so friendly and flexible. Despite of my last minutes request to have party there, they ordered me a keg that I wanted and got down all logistics so that my DJ friends can set up their gear. During the party Drew and Nicole were so cool and checking in with me periodically if I need anything. New HA-RA brought back classy 40's - 50's old skool San Francisco bar vibe. Everyone came to my party had a really good time. Thanks Tom, Wizz, Adam and Nicole. Everything went soooo well!!! 
Love you guys!!
author: Miyako U.

description:
Great crew behind the bar & the locals are an awesome bunch.
Cheers for contributing to making my stay in San Fran a bloody ripper of a time! :D
author: Ad R.

description:
I see the listing as a 'dive bar,' probably would be better described as a 'cool bar.' Why? A number of reasons, not the least of which being that when you go there, right about when you are wondering if you are in the right place - you are just about there...

Three experienced SF bar proprietors (with at least one a local legend) brought this one-time nightspot of wrestler HAnk Hanastead and boxer RAlph Figari, as well as a former brothel, back to its old glory: vintage photos, original ceiling, red-velvet wallpaper, and all (see - a pro wrestler, prizefighter, and a former brothel - three more reasons this place is cool).

It is on a stretch of Geary Street in the Tenderloin (regardless of what the realtors and rental agents tell you) that is still a block or two from a lot of the gentrification that has happened in the area. So get there now if that's your draw, because given how things are going in The City the 800 block of Geary will be tamed soon as well...

Ha-Ra oozes character and stories, which whoever is behind the bar will generally share if they're not too busy. The crowd can be 'interesting' depending on when you're there, it's a great place to catch a game or a drink before heading home. They have a good selection of liquor and beer, and know their cocktails...

I read the Yelp complaints about the pricing, honestly not sure what people expect in SF when here. SF and the Bay Area are not an inexpensive place to eat or drink practically anywhere anymore, I don't see Ha-Ra as being any different better or worse in that regard. It's a great go-to spot for a change of pace, and it's been a sure-fire fun night every time I've been there so far.
author: Arthur S.

description: Had a blast with my friend there and walked out of there mission accomplished.
author: Adan P.

description:
So much for "remaining" a dive bar...yet another TRENDALOIN bore! 
Wish I can tell you more, but I will spare you.
author: Jill F.

description: My favorite place to go in San Francisco on Saturday afternoon!  By far the coldest beer in San Francisco.  This place has been renovated and has a great vibe (old school).
author: Jeff C.

description: Stopped in here on our way out of town Sunday morning for some football. Drinks were fast, free BBQ, and the NFL ticket. Hank our bartender was awesome! I've worked in bars for over 12 years and love when a stumble upon a gem like this. We will definitely come back to this place when we are in the bay.
author: Sarah M.

description: Everything you could want in a quiet and dark bar in the middle of SF. Came here on a Sunday after "dive bar hopping" with my cousin. The bartender was very friendly, funny and attentive (and makes a great drink!). The locals were just as friendly. Major bonus: they have a no fee ATM (compliments of the establishment), which, in such a big city was a huge plus! You never see that anymore. They also have a bad ass looking phone booth that is converted into a photo booth! We didn't have the chance to try it, but definitely wish we had. Just another excuse for us to visit again!
author: Princess L.

description: Super chill place, we went on a Tuesday and there were max 10 people the whole time we were there! We really loved our drinks ($6 Oatmeal Stout and $6 Gin & Tonic) and especially loved the bartender, Adam! Hilarious and knowledgable about the area, fun to talk to and super sweet. Thanks Adam & Ha-Ra crew, we will be back!!
author: Kellie P.

description: We walked in here and waited for a long time while the bartender hung out at the other end of the bar talking to her friends. No bueno! We walked out and went to a competing establishment. Nice bar, tho!
author: Rick L.

description:
This place is dark and divey, the drinks are strong and the jukebox is fun. The bartender was very friendly and mixed up a few Makers Mark Manhattans, we chatted like I've been there a hundred times before. The DYL and "Be about it" Zine party was the place to be last Friday and introduced me to the Ha-Ra Club. 

I love San Francisco locals, they often make you feel at home no matter where you are from. Since, I'm a local - we talk about the ever changing city we were raised in. 

I'm drinking Maker's Mark Manhattans at a steal of a price and finish the night off with an Irish Coffee with whipped cream. I know, not what you would expect from a dive bar, but you always find the best things when you are not expecting them.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Cool Dive Bar with very well priced drinks and decent cocktails. I forgot what I had but they were all pretty good. 
The owner/bar-tender was very personable and friendly.
Most cocktails rang in at around $3.50~5.00
I don't like beer so I can't comment on them.
After all is said and done, it's great bang for the buck!
author: Umesh T.

description:
Snuck in on a rainy Friday after a nostalgic walk through the Tenderloin. The Bourbon and Branch crew are taking over the neighborhood -- people like me who mis-spent their 20s 'slumming it' on Geary might be the reason -- and rumor was the Ha Ra was the next TL dive to get the mixologist makeover.

All the signs of a bar imminently to be sold were there: three people inside, empty space on the dusty liquor shelf, and dead silence. That's rare on a Friday in this neighborhood nowadays -- hearing the building hum as you drink -- and worth pursuing. 'When's the changeover?" I ask, trying to be casual. A sneer. "You can't believe everything you read on the Internet!" says the barkeep. 

He's the lone man on the staff, and on his days off (Sundays and Mondays) the bar is closed. Maybe that's how the hints of the Ha Ra's demise began. Or maybe nobody can believe a bar/social club opened by a boxer and a wrestler in the 1940s, and still owned by the same family, can hang on in 2014, when tech is king.

$10.25 for a shot of Bulleit and a Racer 5. $3.50 for a well cocktail. The lesson on how to hit in a bar fight without breaking your hand (palm strikes) and how to break the thumb of the dude choking you (raise your arm, twist, and pull) from the knuckle-tattooed regular was free.

All bars in the TL used to be like this. Get it while you can, kids; it's on its way out.
author: Chris R.

description:
Best dive bar in the TL.

Look at the amount of 5 star reviews! If I wasn't such a D&$K with my reviews I'd give 'em 5 too.


Totally worth your time and money.
author: Justin S.

description: Thank you team from aces, Scotty and Tommy for saving an old school bar. You managed to modernize it while keep the original feel. Well .... Old school feel without the grim, smell, and sticky everything. It looks great and feels right! Thank you!
author: Michael T.

description:
Dump. Skip it. 

Visited SF a while back and saw that this place was supposed to be a fun dive bar. I'm assuming now that all these positive reviews are just a running joke with the locals because the bar was completely barren when I showed up with my friends. The bartender had the personality of an opened box of Saltines and seemed annoyed to have customers. My friend ordered a jack and coke that not only turned out to be outrageously expensive but was also almost 100% soda. The actual soda that I did order was somehow only slightly less expensive. Naturally I have to assume that they really value their disgusting bar soda to put it at that kind of a premium. 

Seriously. It's a dump. Skip it.
author: Mike S.

description: Solid bar, not a dive bar by any means IMO, pretty dark, tiled ceiling, 3 decent size TVs, water readily available in a self serve style so you don't have to bug the bartenders..
author: Jeff H.

description:
Let me tell you a little something about Ha-Ra, or as the glowing neon sign amongst the filth of the 'loin advertises "Ra."

This is not a bar where you and your girlfriends go to to celebrate your bachelorette party. Nor is it a place where you and your bros from Walnut Creek visit to hit on city chicks.

This is a place where the patron's eyes wrinkle over from years of heartache and disappointment. Where solitude comes on a busy Saturday night in the hood. 

You are almost always guaranteed a game at the pool table, as most of the regulars are hunched over their scotches and whiskeys. 

This is where you can share a pint with the real San Francisco, far away from the glittery lights of Polk street. This is where San Francisco goes to sit, think, and drink.
author: Jenny U.

description:
OMG... With almost 200 reviews I probably won't cover an aspect that's new except to say that upon walking into the place for the first time, a girl in a horse head mask jumped on top of a friend and rode around on the bar and proceeded to have a great time. It was her birthday so when in Rome...

The drinks were strong and the bartender friendly enough that I enjoyed the whole crazy experience. I like the diveyness of the place and hope you do too.
author: John B.

description:
I went into ha ra last night with a buddy. (12-21-13).  I asked for a beer and the bar tender, (not giving a shit) said "they don't have it." Then asked for another beer on tap. His response was "all beers on tap are out." Then he asked me "how much have you had to drink tonight?. " ?!? It was the start of the night and we literally just got there.

At ease soldier, I don't need to give you my money.

I hope this whole place washes its face with a shotgun.

If your looking for a dive in the area go to 800 Larkin.

If your looking for a great beer bar. Go to Amsterdam.

But skip HA RA, it's garbage.
author: Ben H.

description:
My friend doesn't live far from this bar so it was the perfect spot for a surprise birthday gathering. It's surprisingly well lit for a dive bar. I'm used to them being dark inside. There's a pretty kick ass (to quote High Fidelity) jukebox inside and a pool table for those of you looking to shoot some pool.

The bartender is attentive and she didn't mind a group of us taking over the bar for several hours. Drinks are also cheap. Both alcoholic and non-alocoholic were very reasonably priced.

Perhaps there will be more celebrations here.
author: Amy J.

description:
This place doesn't pretend to be anything that it's not.

It's Ha-Ra. What you see is what you get. 

With a laid back, but efficient bartender - who doesn't mind pouring you a glass of water - despite the hoards of boozing santas around her. Solid prices. And plenty of chairs to sit.

Bumpin' to Mariah Christmas Christmas ballads from the juke-box, while Santamonium erupted in the dimly late place, while a grumpy old regular watched - with jaw open - was a great start for a Santa filled Saturday.

Trust
author: Jessica T.

description:
My friends and I want to start out at a dive bar for cheap drinks. We got there and it was dead (it was 7PM on a Saturday). It's too bad that they ran out of rum already! (Where's the rum gone???) 

We ordered beer on tap and it's $4.50 per beer, so it's not bad at all. We didn't order any cocktail drinks because my friends wanted to go to a more "classy" bar.

The bar has a pool table and a jukebox. The people there played some rock music and were singing along as they played pool.

I think it's an alright dive bar but I'd go here if I want a glass of beer. I could give 4 stars but no rum so 3 stars. I still recommend to visit this bar because people have different feelings with dive bars.
author: Vanessa V.

description: Nice bar but these people are crooks, their alcohol is full of water. I had 2 LIT"s and trust me it just felt like lemonade. Told the bartender and still they did not do anything about it
author: Karan S.

description:
Dearly beloved, we gather at bars to get through this thing called life.
Booze makes me devolve and I'm not the only one so don't judge or do I don't care after enough whiskey.
Ha-Ra Club is a divine dive on the way from Union Square to The Polk Gulch, it caters to old men and the occasional influx of youth looking to get downtown with their drink. It's kind of insulting. I'm at that age where I could commit to a bar like this and it would become my second home or just stop in, imbibe and be on my upwardly mobile way.
The drinks are a good price for the city and the TL area. The owner/bartender is blunt, crass and ornery but that's what makes the magic happen.
I love the big clock on the wall and the brick interior as well as the low ceilings because it's perfect.

My most recent adventure here was blur of drink after drink after drink after drink after drink after drink after drink after drink after drink. I'm fairly certain I put a $20 bill in the jukebox and played all Eagles songs, maybe I just put the money in and forgot.
I tried to dance, I refused to play pool, I mouthed off to anybody who looked like they wanted it, I fell asleep in the bathroom(not recommended) and my friends made sure I got home. Thanks guys, I owe you.
Drinking is another reason for so many things as many know but at this place you drink because you have to. Because in this life things are much harder than the after world, in this life you're on your own. And if  the elevator tries to bring you down
Go crazy! Have another pour!
author: Alexander R.

description:
HaRa! It sounds funny when you say it a bunch of times (try it)...and this is what you will be chanting after a visit to the Ha-Ra Club.
A quintessential dive bar- don't let the neighborhood scare you away. It's typically fairly empty and you can almost always get in for a game of pool (unless it is SantaCon and there are like 50 million Santa's in here).
From the looks of it outside you wouldn't think it's a clean and nice inside, but HA-RA (I like to use this word instead of Surprise) it is!
New juke box with all the latest a greatest hits to go with your $5 glass of scotch.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Ha-Ra is more than your run of the mill dive. How do I elaborate.. it's almost too flawlessly divey to be a real dive bar. Not over the top on purpose divey, but juuuuust right.

A dive bar you'd see in a film. Like the owner purchased a Jello mold of the 'typical dive', added water, and out popped a jiggling, marshmallow speckled Ha-Ra. Old crusty bartender, prohibition violation certificate on the wall. Cheap tables suitable only for a dive or a low budget cafeteria. Cheap beer, PBR included (much appreciated as always). Pool table in the corner an obvious must.

People bitch about the crabby bartender but so what? He's like that to EVERYbody. Chill out, it's only offensive if he's being selective. Would you get pissy if a deaf person wasn't listening to you? Of course not, they're not listening to anyone. Same with the bartender, deal with it. He was asked about happy hour and his reply was "Not here. When I'm working it's unhappy hour." Well said good sir, I salute you for your honesty.

Lots of "dive bars" in SF try too hard. That defeats the purpose, if you're going to invest time and effort into a bar why on Earth would you work to make it look uncared for? A true dive just ends up that way, like Ha-Ra. They have booze, they have chairs, and they have more booze. All you need, case closed.
author: Justin N.

description: Love love love this spot!!!! Beautifully decorated and the staff is friendly and on point. It's only been open fur a short while but is killing it and will for sure be a new regular for me.
author: Lauren B.

description: A true dive bar. I remember (barely) doing shots with the cranky bartender back in 2009. It is now a bit of a hipster haven but is still a great spot to down many drinks with a friend or two.
author: David D.

description:
I don't want to sound like a snob but this place is a diver among dives. Coming here on a dive bar pub crawl I was not let down by the attraction.
I had a vodka and cranberry fearing that anything else might be horrible. The bartender was surly despite my efforts to be sweet and wish him a good evening.
I went to the bathroom but did not use it, i chose to see what the next place held. I can say that in a world of gentrification it's marvelous that a place like this still exists, right?
author: Lizzy M.

description:
I don't wanna say too many great things about this place cuz I don't want a bunch of idiots coming here, playing their shitty music on the jukebox and interrupting my pool games.

Cheap drinks, but sometimes they run out of stuff so basically don't be a dork and order complicated drinks. 

One star off because the bathrooms smell crazy. Also, be careful of locking it from the inside. The bartender hates that!!
author: Brittany L.

description:
Aaaaaah, the Ha Ra. Why don't you just change your name to Ca Ra in honor of the man, the myth, the legend - Carl?

In an age where young, hip bartenders are muddling their way to cult celebrity status around San Francisco, it leaves little room for the old school, curmudgeony types like our boy Carl at the 'Ra. He's a straight shooter who isn't afraid to tell you to "fuck off" if you're acting like an asshole and he'll always steer you in the right direction when it comes to your drink order. If he doesn't like it, he'll tell you, "it's crap!" If he approves, chances are he'll crack open a beer of his own and stop what he's doing to tell you some dirty jokes. Without him, I don't think there would even be a reason to visit.

Don't expect a fancy library of malt whiskeys, fine scotch or trendy vodkas... head in expecting to drink well cocktails and Miller High Life (served in champagne glasses, on request). Carl will probably get pissed off about having to wash those glasses afterward, so expect to be the recipient of a few four letter words before he actually breaks out the stemware. It's all part of the fun, though.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Walked in on a Saturday night and it was barren. The power was out and all they served was Budweiser from a bottle and Kentucky Reserve whiskey. It boggles my mind how anyone would want to keep this place open, let alone work there.
author: Chris B.

description:
Dive bar does not cover the description of this place. It's more of a cannonball! Upon entering we were greeted by the funniest bartender I have encountered in my drinking career. He says to our crew, "You guys better be drinking Budwiser's or shots because the taps are all dead." After hearing this myself and the three other chaps I was with kinda glanced at each other with the same thought in our mind "Do we really want to do this?" I'm so glad we did!

We sat and our bartender extraordinaire (Carl) was able to extend the drink menu and rustled up some Miller High Life's from the back for our drinking pleasure. Of course we had to request the appropriate glassware for the 'champagne of beers'. Even though Carl made sure to call us several derogatory names, sure enough he obliged the odd request.  

About an hour after what was supposed to be a one and done beer visit, all three of us were now the only patrons left in the bar 2 shots and 2 'champagnes'  each deeper. 

Why you ask? Carl! He's like my cranky old grandfather only way funnier. He told us dirty jokes, ripped on each and every one of us, and swigged shots of Cuervo every 10 minutes. Even when we decided to leave and go next door he closed up the bar early to have a beer with us there. I don't even remember the name of the next place we went because the Ha-Ra was that good. 

Beware of what your getting yourself into. If you want clean glasses, a working restroom, and an attractive crowd the Ha-Ra probably isn't for you. If you want inexpensive booze and entertainment in the form of San Francisco's crankiest bartender (he was really voted this by a magazine) Carl will take good care of you.
author: Danny W.

description:
This is a pretty standard dive bar.  My sister's boyfriend used to come here often, and one evening I was hanging out with them and they brought me here.  I don't think this would be my first choice for a place to grab a drink in SF, but if you want a no-nonsense kind of bar, this is a good place.  My favorite thing about this place was Carl, but I heard he moved out of SF so he no longer works here.  Nothing beats Carl's dirty mouth, the fact that was he always moderately sauced, and would hit on all the women.  This place has a pool table and a rad jukebox.  I think the vodka shots my sister and I ordered came from a bottle of Ketel that was over a year old, but it still tasted just fine.

I would say the best thing about this bar are that there are no pretentious douche bags hanging out in here.  If you just want a place to get drunk and hang out with your friends in a casual environment, come here!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Carl the bartender was voted by the Guardian as the crankiest bartender in all of SF for '09.  His quote in response to this honor? "Fuck off."

Add in some dark colors, pitch-black corners, a bathroom that hasn't functioned in at least 6 months, a listing in book of SF dive bars, cheap cold beer, mis-labeled taps, a juke full of jazz and classic standards, a pool table, a liquor selection that's as dusty as the bartenders, and a hefty side of sharp, sarcastic wit, and you have yourself a winner. 

This place has been bringin' the dive since 1947, and I don't see it stopping any time soon.
author: Don B.

description:
I've been visiting Ha-Ra, and Carl, for the better part of 10 years.  A few years ago, Carl told me that he was "on Yelp".  I looked up Ha-Ra and there were a couple of reviews.  Now I'm blown away that Carl has generated so many reviews! 

So what's my $.02 Ha-Ra?  I love it!  It's a piece of realistic, non-touristy, social history in wildly popular, ever trendy, and over priced Bay Area.  Every time I'm in S.F. I make it a point to come by Ha-Ra for a few drinks, which is more often than you would think for somebody who doesn't even live in California.  Carl makes this place, without question.  But Ha-Ra does have an interesting history in itself.  Started by Harry and Ralph.  Ask Carl to show you the bullet hole in the ceiling for starters :)

Now if you're looking for a Hanger 1 Martini, or a Mojito, or some other fancy drink, this place isn't for you. If you're looking for a hipster/trendy bar, look elsewhere.  If you want a live DJ and a dance floor, keep looking.  If you're offended easy by a dirty joke and a sarcastic sense of humor, PLEASE DON'T GO THERE!

However, if you want a decent selection of beer, past your typical Bud/Miller selection, for a reasonable price then this is your place.  If you're up for a few drinks with patrons that are real people, who aren't trying to pretend to be something they're not, pull up a bar stool.  If you want a shot of whiskey, or tequila, with your beer you've come to the right place.  If you enjoy conversation with a colorful bartender, who's got a history as interesting as the bar itself, this is your bar.  

Some people call this a dive bar.  I call it a real bar.
author: Ben F.

description: Fantastic remodel.  The guys kept a lot of the original touches but spruced up the space nicely. If you are looking for a cozy space with friendly bartenders and good TVs for sports, this is a great spot.
author: Grace R.

description: stumbled onto this place... Great Bloody Marys and COLD tap beer!! service and Sphere on point.
author: Tanya L.

description: Carl retired and moved to Cambodia.  They have an internet jukebox now.  That should tell you everything you need to know if you used to be a regular.
author: Joshua W.

description:
One day a magical little gnome said come to my magical little place......he spoke and I listened.

This magical place was full of unicorns, leprechauns and jackalopes.  I was catapulted back between today, yesterday and tomorrow. 

Is it clean? Absolutely not. Is it dirty? Eh, not especially.  I would compare it to your favorite pair of shoes you just can't part with.  They have been worn, they have walked these streets down and back again.  They have traveled miles but they are comfy as heck and you'll be damned if you throw them out.  They are not replaceable!  

Ha-Ra is that place.  It's been around a long time.  The photos are nostalgic, the bartender reminds you that they aren't there just to make you a cocktail, they are the bar.  Carl is the bar!  This place is seriously old school.  You don't walk in and order some fancy drink, you come in to chill out on a bar stool, listen to some Jazz and put some hair on your chest.  Last time I was there they had a Noir book night.  Noir!!  What's even more SF than the institution that is the Ha-Ra, Film F'ing Noir!  

This magical place called and I answered....
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
Ha-Ra is yet another one of those SF places that I have deliberately not reviewed, even though I have been there lots of times.

Those of you who knew Carl know what I mean.  What a character.  Recently, I stopped in this joint again and got a new, young bartender.  I give the guy credit, because when I started talking about Carl, you could tell that he had heard about it MILLIONS of times already.  He was very eager to put that chapter behind and make his own mark as a bartender.  Not easy to do in Carl's footsteps, but I wish him luck.  

At least after Carl left, the owner of the bar used to tend there.  Surprisingly young, he is actually the son of one of the founders/owner.  This place has a surprising history, though you wouldn't know it upon casual inspection.  Check out the black and white photo of the Ha-Ra from the 50's or 60's, when it was full of patrons dressed up in suits and dresses.
author: Dave N.

description:
$4.50 beers with a nice selection: PBR, Stella, Prohibition, etc.... Ha-Ra. 

Pool table with lots of elbow room...  Ha-Ra

Chill bartender dude who I pattern my wardrobe after...  Ha-Ra

Perfect for happy hour... Ha-Ra

Holla!
author: Earl G.

description:
I like my bars dark and uncrowded, my floors sticky, my drinks stiff and my bartenders hilarious and my fellow bar patrons unobtrusive. Ha-Ra is everything i could dream of and more. I can sit here in here at the bar and have no Marina m--ther f--ker bothering me, actually for that matter that i can GET to the bar area without shoving some 20-something popped collar douche hitting on Juicy Couture and her best friend and have to pay only $3.50 for a gin and tonic, is my idea of perfection. Top that off with Irving's Pizza across the street...and, well I could go on and on, but i'll stop my drunken blatherings here. Just know that the next time i'm at Ha-Ra i'm inflicting my hideous music taste (Starship anyone??) upon the other patrons at the jukebox. And because Ha-Ra is so cool, they're gonna laugh it off.

Yes Ha-Ra's. Dark, stiff and sticky, just the way i like them. ;)
author: Vanessa C.

description:
This is a cool place with a full bar and a jukebox with a good selection of songs. I even found a Marilyn Manson song on it, "We're From America". I played it of course! The lady who was the bartender there was cool and friendly. This place has a full bar. The bartender offered to make my drink strong as I was barely tipsy although we were drinking for a good few hours. 

The drinks are good and strong and not overly priced. Again, Tom R. was with us and we were all wondering about this guy in the corner there who looked like he was dead. I'm not kidding, he wasn't even breathing. He was in the corner behind the bar. Eventually he moved at some point. It was kind of funny in a twisted way, lol!
author: Butterfly A.

description:
As a disclaimer, I am from Seattle and was only here once but had a great time. This place is very down to earth and laid back. Don't expect anything fancy. 

The owner, Rick, was bartending and he's great to talk to assuming you're not an uptight person. He had no objections to bringing in food as well. 

I'm not a fancy drink person but I didn't see any redbull or lemons around, so if you're looking for that you'd probably want to go elsewhere.

Drinks were very reasonably priced (I think it was 7 for a double well scotch), I don't think they have a happy hour. Rick (the owner) even paid for the jukebox when I was there which has never happened anywhere else I have been. Not too important imo, but still nice
author: Mike W.

description:
A small but decent selection of beer on tap, chill bartender, and everything else you'd expect from a friendly dive bar. 

I was left smitten when I realized that I could get tacos across the street. I was able to take a quick taco break between drinks and make another another taco stop on my way out. 

Great folks, great drinks, and a sprinkling of tacos = good times.
author: Loli L.

description:
I have some bad news for San Francisco dive bar lovers. The rumors are true that the cantankerous bartender Carl has moved to Cambodia. 

I hadn't seen him there the last few times I'd been in but figured I'd just been missing him but this last Saturday I finally asked where the hell Carl was. Rick, the owner, gave me the 411 and we were crushed. The story is that Carl moved to help his friend run this guesthouse in Cambodia http://newaqua-guesthouse.com/ I assume he's bartending. 

Calm down everyone! Carl is gone but lets look at what HaRa still is. They still serve strong drinks and cheap beers. They still have a good jukebox, they still have pool tables, and they still have that great location on Geary. 

Anyone up for a trip to Cambo? 

P.S. I get the feeling the Rick might be getting a little sick of people asking about Carl.
author: Manny F.

description:
I came here for DYL and a great zine party.  I must say that this unassuming dive bar as quickly grown on me.  The bartender was friendly and made me some tasty perfect manhattans.  I know I will find myself here again soon!

This place is worth a stop in if you're in the area and want to avoid the crowds or attitude.
author: Theron L.

description:
One of my first "neighborhood nights out", we ended up at Ha-Ra.  About 45 minutes in to our experience, a group of tourists walked in and were asking for fruity drinks.  The bartender replies, "The best I can do is a Jack and Diet Coke."  You had me at snark, Ha-Ra, you had me at snark.

The Giants game is always on, groups of old Mexican men are always around, drunk and playing cards, and I think there is a regular bar fly named Patty or something.  She's ancient and fabulous.

The jukebox is quality.  One night we were there before the crowds rolled in and the bartender gave me $10 to put on some tunes.  Everything from Gaga to Grateful Dead.  

On that same night, the bartender (owner I think) got a random shipment in of PBR tall boys, so he was practically giving them away.  Score!

Overall, on my list of top 10 dive bars in the city.  Probably the best in the TL.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Oh why not, 5 stars.  It reminds me of the Tattle Tale down at Sepulveda and Sawtelle (PS: if anyone knows that place I'll buy you a drink anytime any place, there will be a simple test involved of course)

It was a Thursday, there were a few old guys, two cute girls at the bar, several hot yelp aficionados at one table, and the pool table from The Hustler (possibly the same one) but with that perfect lighting, or lack thereof.

and yes, $4 pints and a $2.75 vodka/cranberry (although I think that was because Nicole's a hottie. I mean, mine only cost a dollar, but then again, I didn't much trust the way he was looking at me as he slid the drink across the bar...)
author: Mike V.

description:
Ha-Ra. Horrah!

I think Vanessa C.'s review pretty much sums EVERYTHING up.

I started my Santa Con adventure at this bar -- what a perfect way to start the day. Beers were cheap, the ambiance was dark enough so that everyone looked attractive, and even those that were playing billiards looked talented. The floors and table tops were sticky, and the smell of stale beer filled the air. Santas were all around, ready to start a very naughty day in the corner, and having a ha ra ending.

$8 dollars for 2 beers. Not a fancy place at all. Very nice.
author: Nicole P.

description:
You know you're in a dive bar when...

...the owner was conceived on the pool table. Or at least that's what he said. He could be pulling my leg, but I would believe it. Pretty much the perfect dive bar. The main guy there loves to talk (but will also leave you alone if you want), good enough selection of beers, reasonably priced drinks....what more do you need?

By the way, Ha-Ra is not a Korean word. The name refers to the first two letters of each of the co-founders' names (Harry and Ray, I believe?)
author: Mark A.

description:
There's something about this place, that even though I can't find it in my heart to give it more than three stars, I always seem to end up coming back. 

I like the bartenders. I like the quiet, dive-bar feel. I don't like that I keep forgetting to NOT order beer there. The taps are either filthy or the beer in those kegs are 20 years old.  

I'll keep coming back, and I'll probably order beer again, and then get mad at myself for not sticking to whiskey.
author: Mez L.

description:
I should have known better than to expect my Fat Tire to actually be Fat Tire. Let's start with that. I've read the reviews. I should have known what's up. But, well...I'd been drinking, and was mildly frightened of seeing my big, bad TerderNob enemeh, so I kind of forgot. Until I had a sip of my "Fat Tire," at which point I made a face, had my FT-lovin' friend have a sip, and then remembered that the Ha-Ra isn't well-known for its accurate draft beer system.

C'est la vie. 

What bothered me more than my beer not being the beer I ordered/paid for was how gross the bathroom was. Pee on floor! I know I can't expect a whole lot out of divey places, but it would be nice to not feel like my jeans are dragging in a puddle of piss when I go to take a leak. I mean, I don't even have that issue at Zeitgeist, and their bathrooms are bisexual. (That's right: bisexual. Not unisex. Get it right.) Also, the ladies room reeked of manpee, which doesn't really get me in the mood for love. 

Aside from those two little issues, though (and the beer problem amused me more than anything, because it's just a random quirk of the place), I really liked the Ha-Ra. Small tables so you're not stuck with everyone else in the place and can isolate yourself with your little group of friends. The music is pretty good, although it doesn't hold a candle to the awesomes that were being bumped at Whiskey Thieves. There are also cool photos hanging up on the walls...which are red. Oh yeah. Red walled bars. So hot.

I wasn't blown over by the Ha-Ra Club, probably at least partially because its famous super-crabby bartender wasn't working, because my non-Fat Tire was kind of expensive for a beer that ended up not being what it was supposed to be, and also because we only had time for one drink before hauling ass to try to get back to BART to make the last train to the East Bay (we missed it), but I'll definitely be stopping back in next time I'm cruising Geary for drinks and crack. Or just for drinks, I guess. 

However, next time, if I opt for beer, I'm ordering a Budweiser. Maybe I'll luck out and get something fancy instead.

3.5 for fun, red walls, and quirky nature.
author: Ashley M.

description:
I guess I'm just not as amused by filthy bars and alcoholic bartenders as much as other people. I kind of like drinking out of, you know, clean glasses and stuff like that. That being said, Carl is somewhat amusing. He's got a lot of stories to tell and it's funny how beaten down by life he seems even when it's only like 7PM. 

I wish Ha-Ra Club and Carl the best but I don't think I'd ever choose to come here when there's so many other great bars to go to.
author: Aaron V.

description: I have been drinking the same bourbon for over 12 years. I can certainly tell the difference between Makers Mark, Jim Beam and Early Times.  What you poured out of the MM bottle on 12/18 did not come from Makers Mark. You must be re-filling empty bottles. Shame on You!
author: francisco p.

description:
Ha-Ra, what an awesome dive. Rick, the owner, is the man. Will tell you stories about San Francisco when merchant marines used to frequent his bar and even bring out old pictures of the bar from back in the '50s. If you are at all interested in San Francisco history particularly in the Tenderloin area come on in and chat it up with Rick. He's a funny guy who likes to bs with the patrons. And speaking of the patrons, all i can say is you are gonna see it all in here. Got an old man muttering to himself in the corner, maybe a few bold tourists, some young hipster like crowd who play shitty songs to which Rick gives me a 5 dollar bill to put in the jukebox and skip over their songs. Anything strange and this place gets it. 

The mixed drinks are cheap. I'd stick with liquor since some of the beer i got from the taps has been skunked on occasion. 

Expect a dive bar. A place that the point is to get drunk and not to see and be seen. If that's what you are looking for take a walk up nearby Polk Street.
author: T.C. J.

description: I ordered a round of drinks and had a twenty out. The bartender tells me "8.50". WHAT?! Insane. People are here to get wasted...and wasted they get. Not much for entertainment. Although we did sit next to a couple of girls with ultra heavy makeup and eyes that looked soulless. They were putting the drinks down like champions!
author: Siao W.

description:
Ha-Ra is a very cool and old school classic dive bar. Rick (I think that's his name) is beyond cool and down to earth. Great décor and pool table. 

WARNING: if you spend too much time at Ha-Ra you will be drunk, as they don't know what a short pour is...    my kind of place. 

5 out of 5 stars...
author: Marty S.

description:
Once again I've heard about this place but haven't experienced the legendary  wrath of the bartender.
Nice place , nice beer...place to hangout on lazy night...
I shall be back.
author: Dupa B.

description:
The diviest of dive bars I've ever been to in my life BUT still super great find.  It wasn't crowded when I went on a Sunday evening and it was so much fun! There's a pool table and many different types of people frequent the bar. Sure, it's in the Loin but it's still a great place to check out if you want to play darts as well and just chill out. There's not much of a selection yet the environment will allow you to carry a conversation and not feel too scrunched in the space. One thing, for sure, the bartender is an interesting character, to say the least. It seems that he's been there for ages and worth getting to know if you plan on making the Ha-Ra your hangout for enjoying cheap libations. It may just become the place 'where everybody knows you name and they're always glad you came'. 

As I mentioned, if you're walking in their with a suit or a pretty dress, don't expect some classy 5-star joint but if you're a man walking in with a pretty dress, you'll get looked at, most definitely, but it probably wouldn't be the first time the Ha-Ra has seen that.
author: Dorothy S.

description: Anyone calling this place a dive bar is someone who don't know a dive bar. At least not by Tenderloin standards. The place is clean, doesn't smell wierd, nor is infested with the typical Tenderloin SRO dwelling assholes/degenerates.  Once in a while, it is nice to go to a bar just to chill out and not have to squeeze up to the bar and get a drink. Hell, chances are you will have the place to yourself along with just a cople others....
author: Jim B.

description:
We stumbled in here on the tail end of a night spent teetering back and forth with old and new friends alike, and you know what? Fairly appropriate as night-enders go. It's a thin reed of a bar, a small shotgun dominated on one side by the bar itself, and the host behind it, who on this occasion met us with this greeting: "I hope you like Budweiser, 'cause the taps are dead." He was awesome.

Once he explained that he wasn't, in fact, kidding, we took him up on taking on a High Life (he had a few stashed) and immediately razzed Carl about his distinction as the crankiest bartender in San Francisco. I could see how that might be true, but if your mileage may vary, he couldn't have been cooler when we popped in. Of course the fact that many of us (including Carl) were about three quarters in the bag and were encouraging of his litany of jokes no doubt helped us fit in a little. Regardless, in a pinch? I'd pop back any day.
author: Kevin N.

description:
The reviews that attempt extensive analysis of how much of a dive bar this is and how authentic it is remind me of an awful film that i saw about wealth inequality. The film dedicated 20 or so minutes to filming some wealthy graduate students and young professionals "slumming it" in dive bars for the night and talking about how REAL the people were there.

I grew up in a place where people knew their neighbors. This place feels like home to me. 

Rick runs the place like it's been in his family for years because it has. He has some great stories about the city and the neighborhood. He's an excellent bartender.

Carl moved to Cambodia. I don't miss being kicked out of the bar at 11 pm-- right after he poured our beers-- because he was too drunk to keep it open.
author: Katherine C.

description:
I don't understand how anybody could have a bad time in this place. Ok, maybe I can. If you have a bad attitude, or think you're cooler than thou, Carl will put you in your place, and you'll leave with your tail between your legs, and/or a bad attitude about the Ha-Ra. 

I always thought it sounded like an Asian joint, but Ha-Ra stands for Hank and Ralph, the two guys who started the place. I like that it's still in the family, and that it's really the same way it was years ago.

It was noon on a Sunday when we ventured in here (scandalous and sacrilegous, yes, but hey, that's us). We ordered our usual--beer with a shot of fernet, and although they don't actually carry fernet, Carl gave me a shot from his own personal stash. Such customer service.

He also bought six songs on the (amazing) jukebox for me, and he called me "adorable." 

It was a little hard for us to leave, but there are many dives in this city. And only so many hours in a Sunday. But this will be a stop on our adventures, for sure.
author: Rachel F.

description:
A dark red bunker for the drink on Geary Street. Do you enjoy being served the drink by a crusty old man wearing the cap he bought at Jersey Boys? Walk then, like a crusty old man, fast as you can, into the Ha-Ra.

[[SF/X; Frank Sinatra. My fickle friend. The Summer Wind]]

There isn't a tacky fake boobie beer poster to be seen here. No horrible sports memorabilia, no NASCAR crap, just framed b&w pics of old boxers with spitcurls. A windowless hole with a Formica bar top. A cheap cabinet holds spindled Sidney Sheldon and Danielle Steele paperbacks. Did I mention that this place was a dark hole? It is. And the lighting is shitty. Only 3/4 of a restroom worked.

I FUCKING LOVE THIS PLACE!!!

The bartender said filthy words! He had a very gravelly voice! Ha-Ra is awesome! And---and---Stella AND Newcastle---and---whoo...spazzing out here...anyhow, he seemed to know that the crowd was going to change and for the worse! He yelled something like "How does everyone feel about becoming disenchanted with The Ha-Ra?!?" and not two minutes later a pile of about eight Marina creeps oozed in off the street! Is he part of some Douchebag Early Warning Network? Was he a magical crusty precognitive? How DID he know?

I went to a good five more bars the first night I found myself in the Ha-Ra and it was mostly downhill from there. Did I mention that I was very, very drunk? I think I was.
author: Jeremy W.

description: Bored and wandering through the friendlier part of the 'loin, I popped my head into some of my old favorite drinking establishments. The demographics ever changing, couldn't bring myself to order a drink in any of them. I happened upon the Ha-Ra and found a low-key, friendly place with a bartender that actually talks to his patrons instead of checking his iphone. I got a history lesson on the days gone by. I think he must miss them as much as I do. Much appreciated in this day and age.
author: L v.

description:
I am unsure I can say anything about this establishment that hasn't already been said. 

Carl, the tender, is surly, to say the least....but if you work on him and don't let him grumble at you he will eventually cave in and smile. I am quite a fan of the smiling Carl, yet, I am also a huge fan of surly Carl. You will undoubtedly get  dose of both on any given night you are here. 

There is a pool table that has actually been re-felted in this decade, which makes me happy. The Ha-Ra has great brick walls, dim lighting, low ceilings, simple decor with as loungy a feel as you can get with no bands playing or booths to hide out in. 

I can't leave out a description of the restrooms, they are what will keep the faint of heart out of this bar. This last time I went the womens restroom was out of order, and I have to say the mens was no better or worse than the womens; no soap, very little water, no handle to flush the toilet (meaning you have to reach into the tank to flush) and no paper towels. 

This is one of my favorite TL bars, and unless it changes drastically, it will remain so.
author: Drue C.

description:
Have you met the elderly, psychotic owner/operator of this hole? I think I'm in love. He will yell at you, he will call you names for picking what he considers to be "crap" on the jukebox, he'll lock a bathroom or two just for the hell of it. He likes to threaten patrons that he'll close the bar early and drink prices are arbitrarily assigned at his discretion, and vary from person to person. He actually charged Matthew R $11 for a well drink on Friday night. That's ok. We can be just as underhanded and sneaky as Old Guy can be. We also have the advantage of good mental health. 

This place rocks and I don't care what anyone says. It smells, it's all run down, and Old Man behind the bar just might really go off the deep end one day and take us all out with the gun I imagine he has stowed behind the bar. Until that day comes, you can count on me being back. A little piece of backhills insanity right smack in the middle of San Francisco.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Carl does not take cards, nor does he take any lip. He says he's been at the Ha Ra since '92. It's quite possible that he means 1892, but nevertheless, he's a funny, old codger who will make your stay memorable (to say the least).

This is an OG Dive Bar. It's actually written up in The Best Dive Bars of San Francisco with 9/10 dive stars. It's been there since 1942, and I'm thinking it probably hasn't changed much. There's not much goin' on in this place, but a wacky old man, a juke, a pool table, and some crazy CRAZY regulars.

The Ha Ra is to SF what the Smoke Shop is to Seattle. Real Deal Dive.

If you're good to Carl, he might pour you a watered down shot or two..
Top shelf 'Montezuma Gold', of course!
author: Katie A.

description:
First of all, this is more of a neighborhood bar than a dive bar.  There's a subtle difference.  Carl is indeed one of the greats.  He 86'd my friend for saying, "Fletwood Mac fucking sucks."  He's the kind of bartender that'll hand you a five and tell you to pick some songs:

Carl: "As long as you don't play that one little guy."
Me: "Paul Williams?"
"No, the little black guy."
"Sammy Davis, Jr?"
"Sammy Da..NO!!! the fucking little dancing guy!"

He meant Prince.  I should also throw in that when I mentioned SD, Jr, this 1996/"Swingers" douche bag in a pork pie hat and a really ugly wannabe sharkskin suit naturally had to chime in and make sure I wasn't talkin' trash, or jive, or 23 skidoo, or whatever the fuck his people say.  Go suck Joey Bishop's dick, Daddy-o.

Anyway, great bartender, great bar.
author: J P.

description: Good old TL!  Erin S. and I picked out scary-looking bars to try as a stop on one of our TL Pub Crawls and this was my pick.  Her pick is the 21 Club.  It only took a year to finally stumble in after a Olive HH, and.... not scary at all.  Doh! I should have trusted all the positive reviews but dang this place doesn't look inviting past dark in SF.  It was not very busy on a Wednesday night, the music was playing, the barman was pleasant and the pool table was free so I schooled Brian W. while sippin on a nice cold Sierra.
author: Holly B.

description:
I needed help finding some place to drink; Drue came to the rescue and provided me a list of great places close to where I was staying.  I decided on one that she said was on Geary and Van Ness (can't remember the name now) but when I saw the Ha-Ra on my way there I knew I had to get off the bus and go in and check it out, she did speak highly of it after all.

I walk in and there are two drunks at the bar, the bartender, a nice looking pool table and myself, I think this is going to be interesting.  I belly up to the bar and the bartender shuffles over to me and takes my order, "one tall Stoli tonic please" "that will be $4.50" score cheap drinks!  A minute later my drink is delivered, a nice stiff stoli tonic just the way I like 'em.

The bartender comes over and I ask about the boxing memorabilia on the wall and he explains the story to me.  Ralph, the Ra of the Ha-Ra, was a professional boxer before going off to the war when he came back he realized he was 'too long in the face' to box any more and decided to open up a bar with his brother(?) Hank, the Ha of the Ha-Ra.  It was a great story and I was informed that the bar is now own by one of their sons, it's nice to see a bar like this stay in the family.  I really love places that have that old school charm to them and the Ha-Ra clearly had that.

The bartender asked where I was from what I was doing there and I explain I'm visiting from Seattle checking out the dive bars in the Tenderloin, he gives me some suggestions and hands over a copy of San Francisco's Best Dive Bars book to check out.  I soon realize this isn't Carl that I read about in the yelp reviews so I ask him 'are you Carl' he laughs and says 'no he's the pleasant one Jerry' so while I didn't get berated by Carl I did get a cocktail poured by one of San Francisco's original bartenders so that was cool.

I finish my drink and decide to head out, I thank Jerry and ask a little bit more about the places he suggested, both allowed smoking which is a no go for me so he threw out a couple more ideas and I was on my way...
author: Me H.

description:
Carl has old school charm and class.  I haven't been to a bar where the gentleman pouring my Anchor called me 'sweetheart' and 'dear' in far too long. 

And he has no qualms about telling the assholes in the bar to get the f*ck out when they are being surly.

The jukebox (sigh) is perfect.

Nat King Cole, Johnny Cash, Louis Prima, I could go on...

This is a great bar to start out your Saturday night.
author: Alice S.

description:
Pirate Pub Crawl bar #6

The barkeep so didn't even care that we were pirates.  And didn't offer Irish Car Bombs.  But did have Guiness. And somehow we blended into the crowd.  That's saying a lot, considering I had an enormous hat and parrot on at the time.
author: Andi T.

description:
Ha-Ra is by far the best dive bar in all of San Francisco.

I found this place my second week living in the TL and keep finding myself planning my Friday nights around it.  The drinks are cheap (3.50 for wells) and strong; usually, I only have to buy two before I'm about to fall off my barstool.  (I actually saw some guy do this last week.)  

The owner is really awesome and takes the time to get to know his customers.  On the one day they were closed for repairs, I was waiting outside for a friend and the owner offered me a free drink and company.  Though I politely declined, I was touched by his offer.

If you're looking for a great dive bar that won't disappoint, Ha-Ra is your place.  It's the perfect place to relax with friends on a weekend (or weekday) or to catch a quick drink after work.  Ha-Ra I love you!!
author: Stephanie T.

description: They definitely water down their booze. Bar tender kept walking outside to talk on her phone. Would be a good spot to go with a group of friends and kind of have the bar to yourselves and have a good time with the juke box and pool table
author: Dirrrtybird B.

description:
"Don't talk to me!  I fucking hate you!" said the portly elderly bartender to some bloke who, apparently, tried to talk to him.  I reckon the bartender didn't like him, otherwise.  

Cool bar, been around since oh 1947 -- it's etched in the concrete in front of the swinging front doors -- and it's class-dive, i.e. the kind of place Sinatra and his Swinging Drunks would hang out at if Las Vegas didn't have such a hold on 'em.

Cool pool table, too.  I honestly had no problem with hanging out here.  But then again, when I found myself outside with the bartender, and he was fumbling with his lighter, I lit his cigarette.  He looked at me cold hard in the eyes and said, "Thank you!"

At least he didn't tell me to stop fucking looking at him, 'cos he hated me.  Then again, had he done that, I'd be tempted to give Ha Ra five stars.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Two gin & tonics on the cheap on an empty stomach, two dollars and twelve songs on the jukebox, and a tight pool table, and I'm a happy little monkey.

This place is really a pugilist's paradise from a bygone era. The boxing motif is not overwhelming, however. It feels more like it's part of the bar than tacked on like a theme restaurant. I love the jukebox! Normally, I'm a punk / country jukebox kind of guy, and my heart melts a little for some quality hip-hop, goth, or industrial, but this jukebox has soul, and scads of it! Very little "modern" music, just excellent selections from decades ago.

I do regret that I didn't get the Carl experience, though. Will have to come back.
author: Paul B.

description:
Screw writing a review about Ha-Ra, let's call a spade a spade and talk about what it's all about: CARL

Yes, the drinks are cheap, the juke box great, the pool table is passable and the regulars are a riot, but in the bar galaxy, Carl is, indisputably, a shining sun!

Here's to the only guy I flash my boobies to for free drinks.
 
Imagine every seedy film-noir-desperate-fat-guy come to life, add a wicked sense of humor, a vocabulary that would make even a Polk Street gutter blush, street-wise smarts combined with a healthy dose of intelligence and a big, soft heart hidden behind a super-thick layer of sarcasm and you might start to get the beginning of an idea of what "Carl" is.

You haven't lived in bar-ville unless Carl's told you to "go home, get lucky, get laid", buys you a drink, won't sell you a drink, gives you money for the juke box, turns it off because he doesn't like your song selection, kicks you out and tells you he loves  you - all in the same night....

Carl, I raise my glass (and usually, after drink Four, my shirt) to you!!
author: Tatjana G.

description:
The Ha Ra is Carl is the Ha Ra is Carl. 
What can be said about the Ha Ra that hasn't already been said?
The drinks are strong and cheap, the decor is divey, the jukebox is jammed with classics and overall it is perfect. 
Yep all that is true. But that is not what this review is about.
This review is of Carl, the man the myth the legend. 
He is the perfect bartender. Heavy handed, quick with the jokes and surly as all get out. 
You are a beautiful man Carl. Thank you for serving me liquor.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Definitely a place I would go to for a drink. The owner is really friendly and funny. 

The jukebox is good and they have a smoking red pool table! I love it! Plus, it's super close to where I live.
author: Miss C.

description:
Ha-Ra, oh la la.
We were led here after a great dinner nearby, in hopes of finding a cantankerous codger behind the bar, but turned out he left the country.  Sounds like trouble.  He must have taken the good stuff with him.  Instead we were greeted by an amicable young fellow who knew quite a bit about the lesser known genres of the music industry.  That's a plus in my book.  (I don't have a book)
{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{{Here are some details on the business:
Happy street dwellers wandering in, getting yelled at by the bartender~
Regular priced beers, no different prices for local brew, mass produced domestics, or european skunk~
Under-aged college students getting ID's rejected by the bartender (good eye, buddy!)~
Cash Only- on a sa-weet antique register~
Mixed drinks are a little more than decent~
BANG! I must say this: Dirty taps/lines.  The kind where you get a hangover from your first sip, that kind of dirty.  Stick with something popular here, that way you know the keg is occasionally changed and the vendor should be servicing the lines periodically.  Two pours from two different brands had a horrible smell, taste, and flavor.  There are people to blame, but the bartender was so nice he replaced them. (seems like the right thing to do, yeah? Better: refund and replace)

It's weird, because it is definitely an old dive bar, yet they have made modern upgrades that kind of take some of the character and charm out of the dive category. I.E. installing huge bright plasma tv's and an internet jukebox that the bartender has a remote control for!  "nah, I didn't like your choice of songs so SKIP!" 
I would venture to say, this is a drunk man's hangout.  I'm not trying to be mean, at all.  There were a lot of wasted people when we got there, who looked down on their luck.  The bartender was very nice, we even randomly sat next to his wife.  There were people dressed in "business suits" who came in kind of drunk, asking for change for pool.  The bartender had a hard time getting payment for that guy's drinks.  
One guy, who was already drinking before we arrived, started a yelling match- from his barstool- with a guy outside.  That was awesome.  He finished his PBR and left quietly.  He seemed nice.
author: Joshua K.

description:
A classy dive with a brickwall interior and a nice setup for some rounds of pool.  The night i was there i felt like i was watching billiards on espn cuz everyone was so fucking good.

Very deceiving after you walk in u realize just how damn spacey this place is.  Like any dive loads of regulars, but this place is special enough to bring in a variety of crowds...love the old boxing snapshots around the wall.

Oh my god!!! - - GO TO THAI HOUSE ACROSS THE STREET!!!!
author: omar b.

description:
I walked into the HaRa one rainy night with two friends...we were the only ones there which was kinda nice.

The bartender poured us stiff drinks and told us ghost stories (whilst sucking on his asthma inhaler)

good times, I highly recommend it if you need a genuine dive bar fix.
author: chandra g.

description:
I wanted to give this place six stars, but there were several glaring problems:

- Cheap drinks
- A jukebox infused with bop and soul music
- A cantankerous fellow behind the bar, who propositioned my female friend outright for physical relations.  So what if she is young, sassy, and basically "asking for it" in every conceivable way?

Sorry, Ha-Ra.  Get your act together.  Until then, it's a five star shame-fest on you.
author: Sam M.

description:
Haaray for Ha-Ra!...Dive & Alive!
Well, not terribly alive considering besides my table for 8, there were maybe 2 other people in the bar.
I heard about Ha & Ra, the original owners, but I dont think they were there. In fact, I'm curious if they are still around, period. Anyway, our bartender was a delight. What a sweet fellow! One of those simple folk from yesteryear who lives to put smiles on faces... AND keep money in your wallet....
My VODKA-CRAN was $2.75!! 
Thats less than 3 dolla!
I almost fell off the barstool upon hearing that...and again as I write this.

Our group was at Ha-Ra just for some quick drinks before attending GAMH. Before we left, the lone bartender had to step outside..not sure if it was a quick smoke or a long errand...but he just gave a shout telling people "Don't go anywhere", and then he left. This place is kooky, and i like it...a lot.

p.s.  vodka-cran was ordered after I asked for 2 differnt kinds of beer..bartender told me they both tasted bad lately. So FYI, also 5 stars if you want bad beer.
author: Nicole L.

description:
The night I went to Ha-Ra was epic.  Epic in the sense that I got so drunk I don't really remember much of it.  But what I do remember is the surly, drunk bartender who started off friendly but when we started asking for drinks that he couldn't make, got a bit out of hand.

Us - We want to have a shot, what can you?
Him - Anything
Us - Sambuca?
Him - No.
Us - Chambord?
Him - Nope, don't have that.
Us - Fernet?
Him - No.

This went on for several rounds and the more we asked that he didn't have, the surlier he became.  I distinctly remember him stating, "C'mon ladies, I don't have all day".  As we looked around the bar, we failed to see anyone actually waiting for a drink. Finally we asked, what do you have?  His response, what you see.  We ended up with shots of Jameson.  After our shot he started yelling at people to get the hell out (it was 11:30 pm) and that the bar was closing. 

While I was amused by the bartender I doubt I'll go back again...but fair dos for people who enjoy it for it's small choice and small crowd!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Dark, divey, stank...with a bartender who'll drink you under the table.

Dig it.
author: Ryan W.

description: My 2nd Bar I went to during Santacon, the place was a dive with this old dude that's the bartender. He was nice, hands shaking while pouring my vodka and he has no front teeth! ha! He made the perfect vodka tonic, and I found Santa Ruggy and Jessica there!
author: Karen T.

description:
Crappiest Jack and Diet I've ever had, but Ha-Ra still gets four stars.

Seriously. It was about 3-quarters Jack and one-quarter flat-ass Diet Coke. NASTY. But, when you're drinking away break-up pain, a crappy drink hits the spot, I suppose. 

And the dark, austere, brick-walled Ha-Ra is the perfect bar to numb pain in (I chose to numb mine on a gorgeous Saturday afternoon, so the dark part came in all the more handy; keep the damn sunshine OUT!). 

Whether it be of the break-up variety, or the job-loss variety, or any other variety, I imagine the crusty old fellas consistently slumped over at the bar have a whole slew of pains they'd be happy to grumble to you about.

"Crusty old fellas" includes Carl, the bartender, by the way. He's serious crusty business. 

And he makes a damn fine crusty cocktail.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Me and some folks walk into Ha-Ra at 1:30 am, and the surly ole guy, whose nose is a gin blossom like you read about looks at us and says:
"What bar did you get kicked out of?!!?"

Funny, too, cuz we had just gotten kicked out of some place down theblock that didnt want to stay open past 1am.

God bless that ole guy for being the coolest bartender in town.
author: Jon F.

description:
Lady Pestlebottom and I came here for one brief round on Saturday night, and were treated to compliments and free shots from the infamous Carl. He delivered on everything I had expected - berating juke-box selections (and rightfully so), insulting patrons, and attempting to procure Lady Pestlebottom's telephone number. 

The drinkery itself seems to have been recently re-decorated, with fresh red paint and some new-fangled lighting fixtures which detracted from the dive-bar atmosphere. But I did enjoy the old-timey boxing photographs and the painted-on bricks. 

Carl told us that we were "the only people who make sense around here." Then he poured three shots of tequila and drank with us. Though I'm strictly a whisky man, I know better than to refuse a free drink from Carl.

There were several hipsters in the place, much to Carl's chagrin. He rolled his eyes and drank shot after shot trying to ease his pain. There were worse things yet to come, however - a group of about a dozen fools dressed as pirates invaded, and we thought poor Carl would blow his top. I feel somewhat guilty for having left at that point, but the pirates were too much for Lady Pestlebottom and I too.

And to the pirate below I say: Carl implored somebody to end his life as a result of the pirate invasion. In jest, of course... I think. And I did not say he "offered" Irish Car Bombs, I said some douchebag asked for them, a request which was met with Carl's usual disdain.
author: Mortimer P.

description:
The first time I went there I asked for Jameson's. They were out. I asked for Maker's. They were out. Bushmill's? Out. Finally, I asked for 'whatever whiskey you have and coke'. That was what I got. My friend had to leave her drink because there was a fly in it.
The next time I went the bartender gave me some money for the jukebox. I was excited and joked 'How'd you know I have great taste in music?' He replied 'No, I just wanted to see you walk'. 
Never a dull moment at the Ha-Ra...
author: Parisa M.

description:
This isn't a bar you're supposed to like. It doesn't like you, probably, because you're probably a douche. Sorry, but it's true, you're probably corny and self-obsessed and the Ha-Ra will light you up for that.

But if you can chill in a dive bar with some dignity, appreciate the old days when your bartender was your friend and not your slave, you like a dirty joke and a simple drink, you might get along. Helps if you know detective novels, '50s TV, and ask first before playing the jukebox or a game of pool.

This is my bar and Carl's a friend. Because I am not a douchebag. If you are, go to hemlock - Carl is not kidding when he tells you to go to the Hemlock. Or slide next door to Whiskey's. 

This is not a spot for pretense. If you're not bringing any in, stop by. Put your hat on straight and use your inside voice. And tell your girl to flirt with Carl. 

And it's not the '20s, dude, it opened in '47.
author: That Was A Good Drum Break ..

description:
I love the Ha-Ra. Every time I've ever been here, I've felt like I have the place practically to myself. No one's ever playing pool, and sometimes there are a bunch of regulars talking to the bartender, but other than that it's pretty quiet and a great dive. 

There are seemingly about 10 taps, only about 4 at any given time are hooked up. The bartender is always drunk and grumbly, but he'll give me a couple bucks and ask me to play something good on the jukebox.

The jukebox, by the way, is great! If you were my friend visiting me from out of town, and you wanted to sit down and shoot the shit in a great dive, I'd take you here, no questions asked.
author: Heidi G.

description:
Friend or foe?  Iono.

Don't come in unless you plan on buying a drink that's for damn sure.  Drinks are cheap, but the beer tends to be flat and warm.  Or they tend to be out of anything you really want. (At least from my experience.) Best thing to do is just ask Carl to recommend.

Nice alternative to go when the Edinburgh Castle is too packed since it's just down the street.  Plus side being it's usually always empty which means free pool tables! 

Granted it's not usually my cup of tea, it's a complete dive.  Depending on the mood Carl is in, you'll most likely get a good laugh or get kicked out.  But I guess some people like that kinda thing.

Just remember, you go here to drink and maybe play pool.  That's it.
author: Mary R.

description:
Not only did I have fun here, but I managed to get drunk and STILL have fun. I'm the type of drunk person that gets easily bored and is prone to wander up and down the street, looking for a better place to get (more) drunk at.

My friend, a longtime Ha-Ra patron, had been telling me about this place for a while. Honestly, I was a bit unsure as to whether it would live up to all of his praise.
