But lo and behold, it was even better than I'd expected. There really is no better place to get drunk at in San Francisco; that I am now sure of. 

Carl, the legendary surly bartender was perfect. A real fixture! Not to mention he was kind enough to supply me with free shots of tequila. He is a true creepy old man, and called me "Legs" the whole night.  He's most certainly a womanizer, and at the end of the night he was urging my friend to "treat me like a woman all night long." WOWZA! Womanizing has never been so hilarious!

That Carl; he's a real tease, lemme tell ya. He shouted LAST CALL about 4 times that night, and each time someone fell for it and left. My friend and resident Ha-Ra expert/patron of 15 years, explained to me that Carl sometimes does that to clear out the idiots.

The beer was a little warm and flat, but duh...It's a dive bar! I'm pretty sure I would have been suspicious if the beer had been perfect.
author: Pamela D.

description: This pace is definately your classic neighborhood dive bar. It's in the middle of the Tenderloin. The furnishings are tacky and the register looks like it was manufactured in the early 1900s. It has a pool table, of course, with a couple of dusty looking TVs blasting.  I stopped in here yesterday afternoon to take a break from passing out flyers in the neighborhood for my FUNDAYS MUNDAYS event @800 LARKIN. I had a Samuel Adams from the tap. The bar appeared to have a few of its regulars in there and a very nice and helpful bartender (an older 40s or 50s blond woman) seemed to know them very well and treat them like family. The bartender and I had a cordial conversation...especially about that really old register that the bar uses. If you happen to be in the Tenderloin on a lazy Saturday afternoon, I definately recommend stopping in for a drink.
author: Mike L.

description:
This is my favorite bar I've never been into.  Every time I'm standing outside the Edinburgh Castle I just stare at it and imagine what it must be like inside.  I'm telling you guys, it's pretty awesome in my imagination.  Sounds pretty cool from what you guys say, although slightly less scary.  I sorta thought I might get stabbed in there.

Update: This was about Hanaro.  I got mixed up.  I've still never been to Hanaro, but I have been to Ha-Ra since I wrote this and Ha-Ra is pretty dope if you want to get soooooooooo drunk.  I think that's all I gotta say.
author: Nick P.

description:
Only had the one drink here. When I was ready to order my second, the bartender told me has was closing up (Saturday night, not even 9pm) to go drink next door in Whiskey Thieves. So I walked over to Whiskey Thieves and spent most of the rest of the night there. 

No real chance to get an impression of this place in action as there were only 3 customers when I got in and 0 when I left.
author: Lennard L.

description:
When I've gone there by myself or with a male friend the bartender was a total ass.  We played stuff on the jukebox that he didn't like and he unplugged the jukebox and wouldn't give our money back.  That sucked.

On the other hand, sometimes I go there with a group of people for a literary meeting, and when we do that he's nice to us, probably because he likes one of the females in our group.

One good point about the place is that it is almost never crowded.  Honestly, I don't know how they stay in business.
author: John C.

description: We started out here on Santacon, so I'm not sure if I loved the bar itself or the experience. But since it's just a regular dive bar, I'm leaning toward the experience. There's nothing fancy about this little joint, and sadly there wasn't even a mirror in the bathroom! However, our drinks were strong and cheap and the bartender was super nice- even though she was the only one there when it was SUPER packed. It was a nice touch when a random patron jumped behind the bar to help her out, b/c he could tell she was overloaded. That gave the place a nice homey divey feel!
author: Sonya D.

description: I used to go here a lot - I miss the ha-ra.  The star rating on this one is tricky.  When you go in - you know you will be yelled at for choosing a song the barkeep doesn't like on the jukebox, the drinks are awful, you may very well be kicked off the pool table by said barkeep, he will definitely stare inappropriately at the ladies and yet...yet....you love every minute of it.
author: Mac M.

description:
Dangerously strong drinks at implausible prices. Juke box with Slayer and Justice equally represented. Pool table. Giants fanatic bartenders. 

As dives go, it's really hard to top this place.
author: Maryann M.

description:
Quick quiz!

The name "Ha Ra" refers to:

1) the Egyptian god of distilleries.
2) the sound a clown makes when he vomits.
3) the Chinese slang term for "wino."
4) all of the above, once you've spent more than an hour slamming crazy-cheap well drinks at this TL fringe establishment.

It opens early, the only natural light enters through the split Dutch door, and you're pretty much guaranteed to leave feeling like the world became a blurry photograph between the time you entered and the time you finally abandoned your barstool. Needless to say, I'm very glad this place is only a block from my apartment. 

It's got a pool table. Photos of old boxers. Crankily charming old bartenders. And drinks cheap enough that you're almost convinced they gave you the wrong change. 

What more could you want in a neighborhood hangout?
author: John G.

description:
A favorite daytime drinking spot.  Good jukebox, cheap drinks, and within stumbling distance of my house  That last one is truly a must.

EDIT:  Carl (Karl?) is an absolute sweetheart.  Don't believe the naysayers. 

Favorite Carl moment:  Listening to him getting all worked up into a tizzy about something, saying how "they oughta bring back Hitler".  Ridiculous, right?

Two minutes later my friend and I stumble out and Carl's all, "You get home safe now, you hear?"

Carl is the curmudgeon of my dreams.  Also, if you wnt to stay in his good graces, don't play any goddamn Bob Dylan on the jukebox!!  Now Bille Holliday...that's something he'll like ya for.
author: Coco D.

description:
Always great times here.  A sample evening:

Order a manhatten. "Whats with all this Manhatten talk, this is San Francisco."  He mixes the drink and garnishes it with an olive. *Oops* grumble grumble.  Sticks his fingers in the drink tosses the olive back in the tray and plops down a cherry. "Thatll be $3." Awesome.

Hippy friend drops a glass.  Carl: "You damn kids! I aint your damn mother to be cleaning up after you."  Friend: "Sorry man I'll clean it..."  Carl: "I AINT YOUR MAN!"

Pretty girl walks in.  Carl: "Hey beautifull gonna stay the night with me?"
Girl says hi walks across bar.  Carl, under his breath: "Cause if you aint, you can get the fuck out"

Its like an endless joke reel in here.

The shelves are pretty bear so youve generally got to stick to whatever happens to be lying around.  The flip side is pretty much "everything is $3" all night.  Bartender also reserves the right to substitue Diet Coke or 7up when the Coke and Diet Coke stop coming out of the dispenser.   Or six ounce bottles for drafts when the taps get fowled up, which seems to be often.

And when he's out of change or too drunk to make any more drinks last call usually goes something like: "Alright Im done, all you kids get the hell outta here we're going to Whiskey Thieves."
author: Codester H.

description:
Oh, Carl. What would this place be without you?

You just never know what the fuck Carl is going to do. Will he let you listen to the entirety of "Sweet Virginia" or will he turn it off because you're not paying enough attention to him?

Will you be allowed to down that last smelly shot of cactus juice he gave you or will he decide to close down for the night and kick you out?

Or will he nod off and, upon awakening, ask you to wash off the tables for him?

Who knows. As capricious as he is, he's what makes the Ha-Ra so lovable. That and the fact that "Sweet Virginia"'s on the jukebox.
author: SheRat R.

description:
Last night I was on a pub crawl of dive bars.
One of the earlier places charged me $7 for a shot of Jack Daniels and it did not come with either a shirt, an XBox 360 or two free PBR's. 

But we went to the Ha Ra and that same drink is $3 which is inline with the economics of a dive.
author: Marcus R.

description:
If you've nothing new to add, add nothing at all.
Read any of the other reviews that are 4-5 stars.  They're all spot on.
author: Don H.

description:
This is the ultimate in dive bars.  It's always dark and dingy in the bar, but the atmosphere is awesome. A pool table, raunchy bartender, cheap drinks, great jukebox. My idea of a fun place. I was on a really awkward date one night and the bartender broke the ice by pulling out a couple of mini glass bottles of miller genuine draft for us. He then says "it's on the house, I have to celebrate"

"celebrate what?" I ask.

"I lost my virginity last night. It was with my sister, but it was really good!"

...Now that is how you break the ice between strangers.  

My other favorite moment was when I was there with a couple of friends and this homeless woman came in holding a pocket size vibrator still in packaging trying to sell it for a dollar. Man, I wish I had bought it. Then I could hang it on my wall.
author: Jade L.

description: When you're looking for a nice quiet dive bar, look no further.  I found this place with a friend once, and despite the place itself looking amazing, the drinks were really cheap, and the bartender is overly generous with them.
author: Neil B.

description:
our friends from sf took us to this local, hole-in-the-wall dive bar. they raved about it during our walk to the spot, going on and on about the infamous bartender (carl, i presume), whom we missed that night cause apparently he got really drunk the night before (one friend was there to witness it all) and wasn't able to tend that evening.

so, we had a substitute bartender that night who was really friendly. i asked for a white russian which she didn't know how to make, but quickly looked it up and made the drink for me. it cost $4, and tasted pretty good, so no complaints there. their drinks are about $4-5 each, which is awesome. they were having a slow night when we went though and were out of most taps, (they only had about 4 to choose from), but it doesn't seem like that happens often and none of us were bothered by it.

the place was pretty empty when we first entered; plenty of room at the bar or individual tables. there was a pool table too, and a great jukebox. according to our friend, he's inspected every jukebox in tons of bars up and down sf, and deems that this is it. for $1, you can play 5 songs. they have a great range, from "mafia hits" to the rolling stones to johnny cash.

within the hour, the place filled up pretty quickly. people were sitting at the tables cause the bar was occupied (we sat at the bar, of course), and some guys started playing pool. ladies were milling around the jukebox and danced and sang to the songs.  

i'm disappointed that i didn't get to experience the notorious carl, so it will be on my to-do list when i go back up! apparently, he gets drunker than most guests and is known to chuck money at customers, give your drink to someone else (and tells you about it), and asks the girl you brought with you if she fucks on the first date. probably not for the faint of heart, but great if you want to up the interestingness of your night.
author: Jeane C.

description:
4 draft PBRs + 2 shots jager + miller bottle = $20

Oh Carl, you are too good.

The only thing was he called last call around 12:30, which was probably a good idea because he was getting too drunk to pour any more drinks.  I was about to hop over the bar and refill my own beer.  And to be honest, I don't think he would have given a damn.

This bar is great if you are in good company, and they have a pretty decent juke box.  An easy 5 stars.
author: A S.

description:
Carl refuses to serve me if I am wearing my hat backwards! 

This is one of my favorite watering holes. 
I like the fact that when you look at some of the old photos in the bar you can see what has and hasen't changed. Like as an example, the same TV is mounted into the wall. so another words, not much has changed!

Good times await!
author: Jimmy S.

description:
My cousins and I had just finished eating at Pearl's Burgers when we wanted to plop down for drinks and some catching up conversation.  Passed by and entered Swig a couple blocks down that totally turned me off.  Holy crap, that place is not my style.
Thankfully we passed by Ha-Ra and, while not fancy or inviting from the outside, it is a great no nonsense dive bar that really shouldn't be  intimidating for the non dive bar enthusiast.  The music's not loud and there's probably going to be more than enough open stools for you and your friends.  The bartender reminded a few of us in the party of Dwight from The Office so automatic points right there buddy.  He even was kind enough to correct me on how to pronounce Bulleit as in Bullet, not some Frenchy way as I had been used to.  But his Bulleit pours were heavy handed and the beer selection was great (Racer) and I'm normally a beer snob coming from Seattle and all.  I can't wait to plop down for some more drinks and chill atmosphere here next time I'm in town.  
Dwight you're the man.
author: justin c.

description:
Dark and Divey.  I like this kind of place. I liked it so much, it spawned a whole tour of TL bars.  Only saw Carl for a second as it was his day off, he was just dropping something off. Within the short time, he was able to pop off a couple of rude comments. 
I would not go with a large crowd. It is more of a place where you go when you don't what to run into people you know. Go with a friend or two, drink up, have fun.
This wonderful experience:
Saturday 4p
author: Justin N.

description:
Makers & Coke and a Whiskey Sour for $4?  Seriously?  Thankyou, but no you can't touch/see/smell my tits.

But, so long as he keeps his distance, for $4, Carl the bartender can make all the pervy comments he wants!
author: Katie S.

description:
We walked in not expecting much but a good cheap bar. In return, we got prices for a 'dive' bar, but the humor from Carl more than compensated for the premium.

My friend and I agreed that this is a place you go if you want to become a regular alcoholic. The music on the jukebox consisted mostly of depressing songs people listen to DRINK.

Here are some quality lines that Carl's old codger-minded head came up with while we were there. These probably don't translate well unless you were there.

We sat next to some girls he had just helped.

"Thank you ladies. Now, I want to see some nudity!"

____

"Hey girls, do you want a slipper nipple?"

*confused reaction from girls*

"Hey, say what. I'll give you a slippery nipple for a fuzzy navel!"

He also berated people for putting on James Brown and Bob Dylan.  He actually skipped some James Brown songs my friend put in the queue.

Unfortunately these are the only lines I remember. The rest of the night was a blur lost as we passed the clubs that lined the tenderloin's slowly gentrifying streets.
author: Anthony K.

description: Refilling your old bottled with less expensive liquor is a dirty trick. That is exactly what they do here and charge a premium for it. One of the worst bars ever!!  I have reported them to all authorities possible. They should be fined for such an offense.  Not even cool!!
author: Steve R.

description:
Cheap, strong drinks--and a pool table!

Mary R. and I came here to end a Thursday night of too much drinking. We had already hit up Lush Lounge, Vertigo, Edinburgh Castle Pub, and Encore.

What we really wanted to do was play pool. Mary said they had a pool table at Ha-Ra so off we went.

She said if we didn't order booze, the bartender would be pissed. I think this was the beer that put me over the top but it sure tasted good going down. This place is definitely a dive bar. We were the only two women there. The bartender gave us a dollar to put in the juke box. He seemed like a sweetheart to me. The juke box could use a little updating but I think the main purpose of this bar is to get drunk. A couple guys asked us if they could play pool with us. Man, we sucked.

This is one of those bars where you bring the party. I'd add this to a Polk Gulch pub crawl.
author: Cindy P.

description: On a cold winter night, this inside of this place was just as cold as the outdoors.  There's nothing inherently wrong with Ha-Ra Club.  It has a pool table, juke box, and plenty of cheap beer on tap, but it lacks any type of ambiance.  Basically, this bar is the same as a thousand other small bars throughout the country that have have plain tiled floors and brick walls.  Maybe if I had visited on a warmer day I would have added a star.
author: Lucius M.

description:
I love this bar. To me it's Murio's of the TL. Granted, Carl's a bit testy if you don't have a cooch, it's all entertainment all the time in there. The 7oz beers are the shit too - usually we just order them by the 1/2 dozen and just kill 'em off one @ a time. Why more bars don't serve more of those bad boys (Delirium does) is beyond me.

Probably the easiest bar to get a drink at if you're with a friend (lady) who isn't of say, legal drinking age? That is...uh, if one were to hang out with such people? I'm not. Nope. No sir.
author: Justin H.

description: Just another dive bar. My first stop of many this evening. I was not impressed with anything in this bar. The bartender was not too friendly. When I arrived there was three other people in the bar.  Two left when I was about half through my beer, so then it was me and one other man. I do not think the bartender said one word to me for this last part of my visit. Even before, he just got my order, and answered my question about where the restroom was. The beer was a little cheaper here than other places, but not enough to come here to be ignored. I do not think I will return.
author: Steve A.

description:
Carl seemed in good spirits upon entering. Immediately asked how we've been, WHERE we've been even... aww.  

So, this was undoubtedly the first time i've gone to HaRa pre-swerve. I went for a couple quiet games of pool with a pal. And it was exactly what i was hoping for. We had tried to hang at Hemlock, but I just cant do it anymore. the place has lost it's charm. so...

If you want to chill with a friend or two and have an audible conversation while drinking a couple cheap beers or cocktails. This is a good choice. don't play Prince on the jukebox. Carl will slay you. 

4 stars 
(cuz there was no chalk for the pool table in site. i scratched on the 8 ball cuz i miscued. wack!)
author: jefe m.

description: Too clean to be a dive and too divey to be a nice place.  I also wanted to get yelled at by the old guy, not the fat Adam Savage bartender.
author: Joey S.

description:
Based on all the Yelp reviews I read about this place, when I arrived at Ha-Ra on a Tuesday night with my drinking buddy, I expected a gritty, old-world haunt, evocative of old San Francisco legend and days gone by. Instead, I found a place caked in mediocrity, gritty beyond the pale of any divey charm.

When we walked into Ha-Ra at 7 PM on a Tuesday night, we stumbled upon a lonely bartender in an empty room. Not a soul came after us for at least another half-hour, and after downing some shots, they upped and left. Not until 9 PM, when we made our exit, did the place have a few warm bodies in sight.

Our experience soured from the time we walked in. When we sat down at the counter, the bartender, an old man with a stiff walk, came and poured us some beers. I was happy to pay less than $4 for a pint, which in this city is like finding a cheap apartment in a nice neighborhood. However, when I took a sip of the stuff, I knew something was wrong. The beer tasted sulfuric, acrid, and entirely unlike what a pint of Fat Tire is supposed to taste like. While I'm normally not that confrontational, I literally could NOT take another sip after a few tastes, so I sent it back to the bartender and got some whisky instead. Later on, my friend got a Harp Ale, which had the same problem.

Bottom line: I'm a beer aficionado, and the the beer here sucks. If you're sticking with hard alcohol, you'll be fine, but I think it's reasonable to expect a decent tasting brew from an establishment that sells alcohol for a living.
author: Christian P.

description:
First stop pearl burgers at 9:30.  2nd stop HaRa to come hang out with carl and eat the burgers. 
Love it.
Now pass the fries dildo breath!
author: Matt N.

description:
I used to live a few doors up the street.  I have only hazy memories of the place, which attests to the generosity of Carl and the others who manned the bar back then.  

The next time you're in there, look at the ceiling above the bar about halfway down it.  There should be a hole .38" in diameter courtesy of my crazy ex-stripper/hooker/girlfriend.
author: R D M.

description:
If you hate the Ha-Ra, you should have your right to drink booze revoked immediately.  Only a real boozehound can truly appreciate Drunk Carl---whose jokes about his mother might lead you to believe he's an extremely perverted incarnation of Norman Bates---and the barflies who have been coming there since the dawn of mankind.  Don't order draft beer.  The tap probably won't work.  And don't order bullshit mixed drinks.  He won't make them.   Stick with beer in bottles and whiskey.  Take your frou-frou-cocktail-drinking friends to Olive.  

If Carl takes a liking to you, particularly if you are a female, you may find him offering you shots from the pint of Cuervo he keeps in his pants pocket.  And although you may be tempted to play a couple Bob Dylan songs when you see them on the jukebox, don't do it unless you're ready to fight with Carl, which I don't recommend.
author: Jess H.

description:
I made my way down to Ha RA for a birthday celebration this weekend and to my dismay, the famed Carl was....... not there. (sigh). After all the hype I was ready for my encounter with this legendary bartender. Oh well, maybe next time. And there WILL be a next time!!! 

despite Carl not being there, Ha Ra was the bomb, what can I say.

I don't normally like dives but this place was super chill. ice cold, to be exact. The drinks were cheap and strong. the pool table was never occupied for too long. The people were cool. the juke was on point...loving the Marvin Gaye and AL green (could use a few new joints though).  and the bartender was great.  They even let us have a full fledged pinata celebration out front. and, they were nice enough to let us use one of their brooms as the beat down stick. Luckily no one was injured in that drunken reenactment of a 3rd grade birthday party. All in all The Ha Ra club deserves a A+.

 See you soon Ha Ra
author: Lawrence A.

description: I like this bar cause it's not only a block away from where I live, but the owner  is very charismatic. This bar offers internet jukebox, pool table, majority of it's original infrastructure, cheap drinks, and great stories/photos back when the bar first opened. And it's got a cozy feel to it.
author: Kissy F.

description:
F'ing HaRa.  There is no choice in alcohol, the taps need to be changed and the bathrooms are disgusting.  Oh well, it ain't a fern bar!  Carl is insane.  So basically that means, 5 stars. Good old HaRa. Great place to hide from the tards that are in most places.

Oh yeah, and Tom is obsessed with it.
author: Priya R.

description:
This is the only bar in the world where people intentionally come to get harrased and put down by an old codger. Nowhere else will you every willing let yourself be called "dildo-breath" each and everytime you order a drink. Dive bar supreme! Drinks are cheap, but limited to what Carl will make for you. And, P.S. don't you even dare play any Johnny Cash unless you want to get thrown out.

In truth, Carl has a fluffy teddy bear side, that come out a bit, but for the most part, be prepared for some of the funniest insults, most racist jokes, and be prepared to feel the full flavor of Carl's anti-semitism/hate of New Yorkers. I am not even Jewish nor from new York, but boy oh boy was he laying it on me.

Gotta love this place, the only problem is that is all this bar has going for it. You can get your drunk on cheaper at other places, but no place like this will give you the sheer entertainment factor from being verbally abused.
author: Michael M.

description:
I am proud to call Ha-Ra one of my favorite neighborhood dives.

If unkempt bathrooms, bipolar bartenders, and the occasional fly in your drink isn't your thing, perhaps you should go elsewhere.

Ha Ra doesn't claim to be anything that it's not.  Imagine your cranky but loveable grandfather running a dark, dank bar out of his basement....

Yeah, that's Ha-Ra.
author: Carla C.

description: This is totally divey w/  a pool table which would normally be all I need to enjoy myself, but  then they dare charge $4.25 for a basic draft beer?  Really? Where is that money going I wonder since they don't have to do much to keep the place up.  I think I will take my dive bar loot elsewhere - like the Parkside where I can get 4 beers for $4.25 (on Mondays).
author: Sarah T.

description:
Cant approve of this joint.

I have been here four times and the bartender has never been mean to me, but I have seen him do it to others. Sorry but I cannot condone anyone being a butt hole to a complete stranger. 

I also get an eerie feeling that the bar may be somewhat racist. Just look at the photos on the wall and listen to the bartender curse up a storm if Outkast or Howlin Wolf come on the jukebox. 

The drinks are not expensive, but not cheap. Atmosphere is below average.

Ill be spending my money elsewhere.
author: A G.

description: Nice place for pool.  Sad to say they were all out of Bud Light when I got there, and nearly out of Miller Lite when I ended up there on a week night.  Electronic juke box on the far wall, but even with music on I could hear my friend from across the pool table.
author: Beth V.

description: Sunny, the weekend bartender, gets my 5 stars. She is the bartender of your dreams, rarely encountered in real life. Some may say that she is wasted on the Ha-Ra but I think the bar makes a nice setting for her. Her Bloody Mary was the best, and I mean the best, I've ever had! She is smart, funny and a great listener. My lover and I had a great time there last Sunday and are going back again today.
author: solell s.

description:
The HaRa is a blast.
 Carl is as advertised but being that I'm originally from Boston and a Red Sox fan I get a pass,  I get to enjoy the abuse heaped on others while being fairly safe.
The parking garage next door use to be the Desoto cab lot, that might have been the heyday of the HaRa, they opened at six then to accommodate the drivers going off shift. 
Nothing like a bar full of drunk cabbies at 6 in the morning.
author: robert a.

description:
this place certainly has personality, that's for sure.  Its a shithole-in-the-wall; filthy, dark, and PERFECT.  The main reason I go is for the old cranky bartender.  Every experience with him is different.  The last time i went he was alternating between singing me a song while drunkenly pouring a glass of jameson and screaming, "Get the fuck outta here" to the other patrons.  theyre randomly closed, im not sure what the deal is, but ive seen the bartender at whiskey thieves, so my personal theory is that when he gets too drunk he closes and wanders next door.

this is always a stop when doing a good night of TL drinking.
author: CC C.

description:
The ultimate in dive. 

Carl (aforementioned crotchety bartender) is a personal hero. Last time I came here with two gentlemen friends after blowing half a paycheck on one round of drinks at Bourbon & Branch (which don't get me wrong, I also love)  the place was dead, so Carl gave me money to pick 10 songs on the jukebox, then proceeded to reel off a list of songs I was not allowed to choose. I wish I could remember more to warn you against, but after a few rounds of cheap whiskey all I've got for sure is NO BOB DYLAN.

A Tenderloin institution not to be missed.
author: Katie C.

description: Great place to chase off a hangover. Everyone is nice and doesnt bug you.
author: Kevin B.

description: By the time I got here last night, I was so drunk I locked myself in the bathroom and had to call my friend to come let me out. I feel like that kind of thing happens a lot here.
author: Maria D.

description: Nothing cool about a glacially slow geriatric dickhead bartender.
author: Adam Z.

description:
its glorious. from now on i will hop twixt ha-ra and whiskey thieves while hanging out with my degenerate hyde st. pool shark posse as it is still within the requisite 2 block radius of the 'hub.'  

you can come git yer learnin' on as they are stocked complete with trashy paperbacks, and feel transported into the ever glamorous but faded dusty crotch of yesteryear whilst perusing the various black and white boxing photographs on the walls. the old man bartender said i gave him an orgasm when i read lines of trashy smut from random novels to the crowd. i'm good at that because, you know, i do the different voices and stuff.  that was a proud moment for my people. i'm sure.
author: Karen K.

description:
Carl says to me "I got my Viagra mixed up w/my Ex-Lax. I don't know if I'm coming or going."

If I wasn't already married...
author: nic d.

description: Pool table, Jameson on the rocks, and being able to snag a stool at the bar make this a great place to just hang out with friends and strangers alike.  The only weird thing is the WIDE open window in the bathroom.  Be aware.  That's all I have to say.
author: Ivy R.

description: Ha-Ra is my favorite club in the city and the only one I go to when I have something to celebrate.  It's unpretentious and easy to fit in which is a great thing in San Francisco now that it's getting stuffy and overrun by people who have too much money to spend.   I don't expect to be impressed by what bars are like in atmosphere because it's who goes there that impresses me most.
author: Jin W.

description: I'm sure he's not the only bartender that works there but the one that served us was sleezy, disgusting, rude and offensive. He made suggestive comments to all the women and complained about having to serve such a large group. There was maybe 8 of us. Give me a break. It's unfortunate since we all loved the bar until we had to deal with the bartender. Definitely a dive bar, the drinks are cheap, there is a jukebox and plenty of seating. Disappointing to say the least though.
author: Heather L.

description: As far as dive bar goes this one is a four stars.  If dive bars in colorful neighborhoods aren't your thing then go to Chambers around the way.  The bartender will not make cocktails unless you have a nice smile and a nice pair of twins.
author: Amber L.

description: I have been to dive bars before. This is one of them. I am not too sure where people go for drinks, but $6.00 for a Jameson is not well priced at all. Hype. People are drinking the kool-aid.
author: Jason S.

description: Four stars on the name alone. Second only to the "Hotsy Totsy", for cachet.
author: Andy R.

description:
True story: I once went to Ha-Ra sat down and ordered a Boont, Carl went to the Boont tap and poured it for me, I paid, started drinking it and realised it was an Anchor Steam? Next I ordered a Prohibition, Carl went to the Prohibition tap and poured but it was far too light for Prohibition... because it was an Anchor Steam! A moment later my wife came over and ordered a Liberty which also ended up being an Anchor Steam.
Story #2: I once fixed the men's room for Carl and drank for free all night.
I wish I still lived in the Tenderloin.
author: Matt E.

description: Ok, not the cleanest place in the world.. but it served us perfectly for our needs last night! Hubby wanted to go somewhere for his birthday to just hang out, have a couple of drinks, and play some pool. So, we ended up here and that's exactly what we did! Drinks were well priced, we didn't have to deal with a crowd, and they had good music on the juke box. Still hate it when you have to pay for music at a bar, but oh well. We didn't have Carl, it was a woman bartender, and she was nice. Will probably end up back there!
author: Stephanie K.

description: I'm not sure what to say about this place.  the beer is fairly cheap, and on a saturday afternoon, the group of eight people I cruised in with were pretty much the only ones in te bar.  It was nice & quiet, and we got a few terrible games of pool in, but really, there's nothing special about this place.  I'm thinking that nobody else was here because there are better options on a saturday afternoon.
author: Andy G.

description:
The bar stinks, the drinks are watered down, and Carl is a rude pr_ck.  I was in there with my boys kicking back sme barley pops and big Carl has a coughing attack and spits some junk in my pal's beer.  I had the "gall" to ask Carl to replace the beer and he muttered some gibberish about living hand to mouth and he can't afford it.  I almost jumped the bar.  
Yo Carl, the little hero worship on here makes me sick.  Because of you I will never step foot in that feces smelling dive again.  Go to a classy joint like the 441 Club or Cinnabar.  Let this _hithole rot.  Good job Carl.
author: TJ R.

description: Most serious dive in the world. In an awesome way. It's a perfect spot to go to after a show at GAMH and a perfect way to get wasted for super cheap.
author: C P.

description: I only come to the Ha-Ra every once in awhile now, but this was the place that I called my home away from home for a good few years back in the early '90s.   I was going to the Ha-Ra back when hookers lined the streets of O'Farrell, Leavenworth, Post, Jones, and Geary. Back before Carl, as a matter of fact (Fat Tommy was the main bartender when I lived in the neigborhood). Ah, those were the days (as far as I can remember them, that is).   Carl makes any visit fun with his cranky ways and his funny comments. Lately, the shelves are looking a bit barren, but they always have something you can drink while you enjoy the quirkiness that is the Ha-Ra.  The owner, Rick, is a really good guy as well.
author: Scott M.

description: I *heart* the crazy ass bartender of this shit hole. Just remember, if he didn't make you cry and you think he likes you, it just wasn't your turn. Cheap drinks and cheap insults. Love it.
author: LisaMarie C.

description: Carl is definitely on the list of best loved bartenders in SF, Lifer Class.  Genuinely divey but very friendly, decent drinks, a good TV and a playable pool table. The old men who live here are not shy with their opinion but are generally respectful to you and your lady friends.
author: patrick g.

description: Yeah this place is funny. The owner/ bartender was telling me how he hates people and stuff. He was spitting out insults to everyone besides me too. I think he liked me. The decor is from the 1920s. I didn't like some duffus that was sitting next to me and talking a lot of BS. I really should have just hit him in the face. There were people dressed here in 1920s flapper style clothes. I guess this sarcastic cynical place is original for San Francisco but in Philly it would just be normal. Cool place though.
author: Jason W.

description: A great old dive, named for the original owners Harold and Ray. Exellent juke box, pool table just good enough for a casual game. Have a couple drinks and squint, you can see your dad sitting down at the end of the bar. Jerry's the Good Cop bartender, Carl's more curmudgeonly but a pretty girl in your party will loosen him up. Please no one go to Ha-RA though, you'll ruin it.
author: jim b.

description: Meh -- I don't see the appeal of this place like some others do, I guess.  Judging from the autographed photographs on the wall -- this place was a boxer bar back in the 40's...and it still has that atmosphere.  Oppressively low ceiling (especially behind the bar, where your eyes are pretty much pinned to the ceiling), not much decor to speak of, not much of an alcohol selection....not much of anything.  If you're going to a bar just to drink -- why not just go to a liquor store and drink at home?  This bar was just about as entertaining.
author: Eugene F.

description: So my roommate Dave and I are all fucked up after a night of drinking at new dive bars in our neighborhood (lower TL) when we stumble into the half door and into the time warp of this place.  Apparantly, according to the older gentleman behind the bar, this place used to be a boxers bar:  A place where boxers would hang out and get drunk and the locals would come to get autographs and catch the big bouts on their television, the original of which is still in the corner of the back of the building towards the jukebox.  Anyways, the bartender told us to stay away from the tap beer, so we did, and we drank bottles of high life and reminisced and got drunker...than we stumbled to some other place and kept drinking...anyway long story short, this is a great place to hang out and catch a drink if you are drunks like us on a tl pub crawl...the end.
author: Francis K.

description: If you don't mind getting yelled at by the bartender then you will love this place. Dark out of the way hole in the wall for you and your friends to play pool in and meet the color full locals. DON"T order anything more extravagant than a jack and coke, or you will get the wrath of Carl.
author: pascale p.

description: Ha Ra is an awesome place.  An angry bartender (Carl) who will sexually harrass you but give you free shots if you're wearing a low cut shirt.  And the guy at the video poker machine has the BEST button on his hat "My shit's fucked up".  That's Ha Ra. I love Ha Ra.
author: Callie N.

description: stopped in last night and met the owner, rick, 2 jamesons and a draft for only $16.25, now that is cheap, rick is super cool too.
author: Pickle R.

description: I miss the long days & nights we used to spend at the Ha-Ra. Carl is the only bartender in town who has hands as soft as a baby's ass. Seriously, how does he do that?! Anyhow, this is a dive bar, it's not for everyone, but it draws a very fascinating mix of drunks. I've seen the Bukowski club, drunk Marina girls puking in the loo, some guy falling out of a wheelchair that I'm not sure he needed other than being half passed out. But my favorite are the old timers, they always have great stories are most of them are locals and can tell you all about SF and the times of yore. Anytime I head to a show in the TL I stop in to apologize to Carl for being so remiss in my adoration for the bar.
author: Colleen B.

description:
bartender is the type of lecher i hope to be when i am old.  drunk, funny and just does not give a fuck but not as intimidating or mean as other yelpers say, unless you are a real bon-jovi looking tool.  but then i suppose there is no help for you.

four stars for experience only (i will probably be back).  drinks are horrible.
author: Markus B.

description: This is a dive bar for people who work in dive bars. I stopped by on a Friday night to get my drink on before heading back to the east bay for my shift at another dive bar. The old timer behind the bar was alright with me and gave me some great background on the joint. I don't like Miller High Life one bit but they sell them in little 7oz bottles that look like little cute treasures and I can't resist that. Good prices, not overtly dysfunctional old timers and pleasent customers (consiering the neighborhood) made my evening and time at the Ha-Ra worthwhile.
author: Benji T.

description: Ok, to be honest this review is about the Ha-Ra circa 1997: GREAT! Used to get a pint for $2.50 to $3. Guys would be snortin crank off a car key outside. One night Bill Clinton drove by (actually chauffeured by) and we cheered that b.j.-lovin' good ol' boy. Carl was cool (maybe all the hipsters/Marina flotsam has grown to annoy him over the last decade).
author: James B.

description: My first night at the Ha-Ra, Carl told me I have pretty hair. When I tried to say thank you, he told me to shut up. He then let me and my girlfriends crawl up on the bar and take pictures. Good times.
author: Nikki H.

description: Place of Carl's home cooked doughnuts!!!  This place is interesting and classic, it feels like being on a movie set and the jukebox isn't too bad either.....
author: Steven K.

description: I was looking for a quiet little bar to kill sometime before meeting a buddy for a movie on Van Ness one recent evening. This spot was perfect. With its worn tables and random photos on the wall the interior looks like it hasn't been updated since the Eisenhower Administration.  All that and a top-notch beer selection, too. The bartender said the place gets hopping after 9 p.m. but at 6 p.m. on a Thursday night, it was a restful place with no pretentions where I could sip a pint and read a magazine article in peace.
author: Steve O.

description: While the hipsters come and go and come again the Ha-Ra manages to stay true to itself.  It boasts one of the best signs in the city and the drinking begins well before the sign is illuminated.  If you don't feel like getting your drunk on, or if you are short on cash, the Ha-Ra serves the smaller bottles of Budweiser.  Buditos, I like to call them.
author: L W.

description: The Ha-Ra is a cozy little stop on the way to a show in the area. Carl's a total card, a vintage video game console collecting card. He kept waving a bag of old atari 3600's at me the last time I was in there. The regulars are usually pretty entertaining and friendly. There's always the novelty of of the baby-beers. Carl will veto your juke box selection if he disapproves. I appreciate that.
author: Steven C.

description:
reminds me of a bar in south dakota i worked at one time. wood floors and bar. one lovely bartender playing the box lottery game & a jukebox. 
perfect, really.
author: aerin w.

description:
Five stars for being among the best of what it is - a genuine SF dive bar and an enduring institution. For those that confuse dive and non-dive bars, keep in mind that this is the kind of place where the bathrooms probably don't work, the bartender will serve you when he damn well pleases, and any drink with more than two ingredients will be sneered at and probably denied. You can order your fancy bullshit drinks down the street at Swig or the Ambassador. 

This place generates a usually pleasant but inconsistent crowd. Most nights you'll be served by Carl (see any other review) and some nights it will be Jerry, the slower-paced day guy. There is occasionally another fill-in bartender - you'll know her when you see her. They have a great juke box, a serviceable pool table and they'll play your sports if they can get the channel. 

I have a lot of "friends" who won't come to this bar because of the haphazard bar service, limited drink selection and overall scuzzy atmosphere. But it is those deficiencies that maintain the Ha Ra's reputation as one of the least pretentious bars in San Francisco. You don't come to this bar to pick up women, impress your date, or to increase your ridiculous hipster street cred. You come to this bar to drink and relax.
author: Phil D.

description: Me and a buddy came in here because it was too packed at the Edinburgh Castle and we just wanted to have a chat.  It seems the place is attached to a hotel of dubious quality and ill repute.  A drunk Korean hooker in her mid to late 30's came up to us while we were talking, yelled at us about Jackie Onassis, then tried to kiss both of us on the lips while attempting to rub her crotch on my friend's knee.  That was the first and last time I went in here.  I'd go back if the hookers were gone.
author: matthew w.

description: If I wanted to get yelled at, I'd go home and hang out with my dad....at least here, they have beer.
author: Margaux S.

description: If you like your bartender old and crotchety with nothing but insulting things to say to everyone then this is the place for you.
author: Corey V.

description:
Deserted on a Monday night.  

Jerry was a sweet fellow.  

No scotch available at all.  

Still, for authenticity, an available pool table, and a cheap jukebox, Ha-Ra would be my local watering hole if I lived in the area.

**
Visited in January 2008 on a Saturday.  The Club was jumping due to a large party observing some woman's birthday.  Carl was in character, or so I thought.  .  And then there was a misunderstanding after a round of Tequila Sunrises were ordered.   Carl refused and instead just poured shots.  One lady objected to the price, and then he ordered their whole party to "get the fuck out."  Carl insisted he was serious, threatened to call the cops, and told the lady that he'd better not see her face in there again.  She responded that he was just an angry old man.  Carl said, "I bet your dick is bigger than mine, you bitch!"   Many bitter words were exchanged, and Carl's parting shot, after the whole party had exited, was "Happy Birthday, cunt."

Upgrade to five stars based on that experience.
author: Daniel M.

description: I love drinking with old school drunks. You know, those guys who have decided to become career alcoholics and have spent the better part of 25 years sitting on bar stools and b.s.-ing with the rest of the barflies. I find them amusing, but also people who have tons of stories to tell (albeit most of the stories start "this one time, I was drinking at a bar"). The Ha-Ra provides me with a plethora of these professional drunks who seem to be there no matter what time of day I go, and ones that are definitely willing to get into long conversations with me. I love the grouchy bartender who gives me jukebox money. I love that the jukebox has a great selection of older tunes. I love that the bar serves High Life on tap (even though I pretty much never order it). I love that I can sit at the bar reading and no one bothers me. Basically, to sum it up, I love the Ha-Ra.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
i finally made it to the ol' ha-ra tonight

well let me tell you with all the heartfelt sincerity in the world that this place was the shit.

I was completely hammered (from drinkin gasoline and raw eggs on my porch).  I ask for a G&T.  That guy carl who everyone desires tried to pour me a nice 3/4 to 1/4 gin vs tonic.

i got so f'ing sick after that that the cops drove that motherf'er off to jail after that, and the ha ra club closed for good.

Ha RA!!!
author: Rocco B.

description: Thank you Ha Ra for giving me a night to remember!  Carl is the most hilarious drunk bartender in all the land.  As long as you order a bottled beer and nothing that requires sobriety and thought to make you should be good.  Interesting crowd, a bar that is stuck in time, and a bartender who is so insulting its entertaining.  It's as authentically dive-y as it gets, and I love it.
author: Em S.

description:
You guys hype Carl up too much.  I went in expecting to be harassed, abused, and insulted.  I got nothing but a nice attitude and good conversation. My friends and I went across the street bought food, and brought it back to eat at Ha Ra.  We ordered some rounds, played whatever we wanted on the juke box, and played some pool with no complaints.  We even ordered a round of Irish Car Bombs, which they made to our liking, with no quarrels.

I think this is a great local bar, where you can go and just relax and have a drink.  No nonsense, just the way I like it.
author: Idin K.

description: I'm sorry, there's just something about the Ha-Ra that draws the folks to it. I'd been there a couple of times during my stint in San Fran since we lived in apartments close by. I only have one word/name to describe this place: Carl. Here's a tip: don't order anything from the drafts. You'll send Carl into a flurry. What you order better be in a bottle and it's gonna be a pony. Other than that, it's quite the dive right on the Tender-Nob that is Geary St. Just sit there and take it all in...you're in for an experience.
author: Michael B.

description: Bartender was cool, played some pool and chilled with a bunch of friends. This was stop number 2, just after the nearby Endinburgh Castle pub, on my birthday crawl. It didn't smell, had good drinks and few people- which was good for it's size. Overall it's a great, low-key dive bar to hang out in. HA RA!
author: Cassy R.

description: I love bars in the tenderloin and have heard people rave about this bar and I just don't get it.  I've been here 5-6 times and it has always been blah.
author: Ed B.

description: I found myself in the TL with some old friends gracing our presence from Colorado. Knowing our past seasoned knowledge of dive bars and fun times we found ourselves in the TL. Also we found ourselves at the Ha-Ra!! Ha-Ra!!! The bartender was RAD!! I could tell he had been in the business for a while knowing the style of old fashion drinks I order. Its hard ordering from someone who isn't skilled in their profession. Anyhow I also appreciate the fact he could handle this lame patron who obviously was visiting the city without style! Thank you bar mate!! I think your name was Casey or Kevin Oopps! Sorry don't recall. Anyhow, you were fun with style and class!!
author: sarah k.

description: I ran into the bar to meet a few friends on the whim. I was not aware the bar was CASH ONLY. I had my credit card in my hand completely visible the entire time i sat at the bar(few minutes because it was busy) I ordered a beer, card still in hand, the bartender poored it, and i went to hand her my card and she said cash only, WHY didnt she bring it up when she saw the card? blind? I told her I couldn't pay (its 2012 really lets get a card machine why don't we) and she gave me a REALLY hard time when I told her I couldn't pay, even after I apologized and didn't even SIP my beverage. I'm sorry but she should have mentioned as she saw my card on the bar waiting to hand her before I paid. They have an atm machine but it would not take my card, I had to borrow cash from a friend. The situation would have been more bearable if the bar tender wasn't a complete bitch about it. We all have bad days, I think she could have been a little nicer considering i was polite and up front off the bat. I payed her the cash when I got it 20 minutes later, didn't even touch my beer and left. Will not be going back.
author: Erin L.

description: I used to live around the corner, and this is one of my favorite bars in the city. Carl is great, and the boxing memorabilia is real- not ordered off of ebay for "atmosphere." The drink prices can't be beat.
author: Mark H.

description: Oh where  to start about this dive. The bartender whom I will not name, will stir your drink with his finger. He will cuss at you for playing the Hollies, Carrianne. (sorry i like that song, and the hollies for that matter). The place is just a block away from the GAMH, to meets your peeps before the show. They have baby millers. But at the end of happy, I'd give it six stars if I could...
author: wayne s.

description: Ha Ra is one of the better bars in the T.L. If you can go on an off night, it is a wonderful place to take a friend to catch up...nice and quiet...pool table. I gave 4 stars b/c lately, on Friday and Saturday nights, the crowd is strange.
author: L T.

description: Wow. I reviewed this place way back in 2005 and it is in dire need of an update. So, first of all, I hung out here tonight with our newly minted Seattle Yelp Community Manager, Katie, and this is by far the best Wednesday night I've had in awhile. So, after dinner at Red Box we decided to grab a few beers and talk some shop. It was pretty much dead in here save an old man with a dragon cane, a gash on his head and one black glove and a couple (?) at the end of the bar plugging money into the juke. We were chatting it up with Carl, our gracious bartender giving us obviously watered down tequila shots whilst telling us Monica Lewinsky and Michael Jackson jokes. Carl would take a minute to bark at the old man at the end of the bar and take breaks to flirt with my companion. Katie rolled with the punches and even talked about Seattle bars he almost worked in with him. The heavily tatttooed man at the end of the bar surprised me by spouting his love for KC and The Sunshine Band and even reminisced about one of the great concerts of theirs he saw. This guy going to see The Sunshine Band was about as foreign as me at a hip hop show. Soon it was just the two of us in the bar rocking out to Patsy Cline and watching a random woman come in to use the bathroom while Carl gave us his mixed up Viagra/Ex Lax jokes (he didn't know if he was coming or going... badaboom!) I've been here before shows at the GAMH, but those nights don't hold a candle to tonight, and even though Carl said he didn't give a shit if I come back (he took quite a shine to Katie) I'll definitely be back here much more often even though my experience won't be nearly as fun as this night was...
author: Michael E.

description: Let me be the first an probably the only one in all of the world to say that I love this bar. This bar is a god sent to any one who hates the fru fru cocktail lounges of the big city life. My husband frequented this bar a couple nights a week after work while we were dating. He had told me all about Carl and Jerry and how I needed to come have drinks with him as soon as I turned 21. So my first bar  was the Ha Ra Club. It has all the warmth of an ice cold beer and smells like sweaty cab drivers. I love that its dark and dank. I love the history behind it and the fact that every one for the most part is a regular. I like to go into my bars and not have to say my drink a thousand time to 4 different people. I like knowing that when I get off work I can go into a place and my drink will be ready for me as soon as the bartender sees my face. It is very true that this bar does not have a good boos selection and a Cocktail Nazi but I love Carl and my needs are simple. It is not a bar for the social scene it is a bar to go have a drink, watch sports, maybe play pool, and maybe shoot the shit with the drunks. The Ha Ra  is the anti cocktail lounge and that is something that I find charming.
author: Nichole S.

description: old school dive for true 'loin drinkers. seems like most of the patrons are solo, drowning their troubles in their pint glasses. feisty bartenders make getting a drink a humbling experience. this was a stop on a bar crawl that i attended once and the bartender threatened to close the bar if we didn't leave. he also wished vd on a friend of mine. very entertaining.
author: Dean E.

description: its the HA-RA. we were here the other day blowin up M1000s out front and carl obviously wanted to have nothing to do with our childish behavior and immediately 86'd. theres nothing to review about the HA-RA, its a bar for drinking booze.
author: christopher a.

description: A great place to do some solo drinking on a Saturday afternoon if you haven't got anything else to do.  If you order a shot of something make sure you chase it down with one of those midget beers (they carry both MGD and Hi-Life).
author: Joe C.

description: i was briefly a regular at this place, because carl thought i was james cameron, and he would give me free whiskey and ask about my upcoming movies. then he got mad at me for not coming around as often as i used to. then i stopped going altogether. but i still love it. the bombed-out bathroom is amazing too.
author: steven w.
